 Landscaping  can  make  your  yard  feel  like 
 an  oasis  or  it  can  quietly  drain  your 
 time  and  even  more  importantly  your 
 wallet  if  you  make  the  wrong  choices. 
 Today  I  am  breaking  down  some  common 
 landscaping  mistakes  that  might  seem 
 small,  but  they  end  up  costing  you 
 thousands. 
 Most  people  completely  overlook  this 
 when  planting  trees,  but  done  right,  it 
 can  actually  lower  your  bills  and  boost 
 your  home  values.  done  wrong, 
 well,  it'll  cost  you  way  more  than  just 
 a  dead  tree.  Mature  trees  in  a  well 
 landscaped  yard  increase  home  values  by 
 7  to  19%  and  that's  by  records  of  home 
 sales.  They  also  remove  pollutants  and 
 sequester  carbon.  If  you  plant  the  right 
 tree  in  the  right  place  that  screens 
 western  and  southern  sun,  they  save  $6 
 to  $270 
 per  tree  in  energy  bills.  It's  easy  to 
 remind  ourselves  how  valuable  trees  are 
 when  you  just  go  try  to  buy  one  at  the 
 nursery  and  that  growth  makes  them  more 
 and  more  expensive.  So,  what  this 
 reflects  is  as  trees  grow,  they  become 
 more  valuable.  So  if  you're  not  caring 
 for  the  trees  properly,  then  you're 
 risking  losing  value.  And  one  of  the 
 worst  abuses  I  see  of  trees  is  pruning. 
 What  we're  trying  to  do  with  proper 
 pruning,  which  is  mostly  thinning,  is 
 encouraging  these  trees  to  get  big  and 
 mature  because  that's  when  they  maximize 
 their  ability  to  do  everything  they  can 
 do  for  us.  Improper  pruning  where  we're 
 doing  heading  back  cuts  is  terrible  for 
 trees  and  violates  this  rule  of  trying 
 to  get  them  as  big  as  possible  and  as 
 properly  shaped  as  possible  so  they  can 
 maximize  their  value.  And  the  other 
 thing  is  we're  never  going  to  get  there 
 if  we  don't  stake  them  properly.  And 
 when  we  stake  them  properly,  they  can 
 stand  on  their  own  very  very  quickly 
 just  after  a  year  or  two  because  we're 
 doing  staking  that  allows  them  to  move 
 sometimes  with  only  two  stakes.  We  have 
 this  photo  here  showing  a  tree  that  fell 
 over  even  with  two  stakes.  And  now  with 
 three  stakes,  we  have  it  extremely 
 stable  and  still  able  to  move  because  we 
 use  flexible  tree  ties  in  a  figure 
 eight.  This  next  one  is  one  of  those 
 things  you  don't  notice  until  it's  too 
 late.  And  by  then,  fixing  it  isn't  cheap 
 or  easy.  There's  two  things  you  really 
 need  to  focus  on.  A  lot  of  the  water 
 comes  off  your  roof.  Some  people  have 
 gutters.  Then  you  focus  on  where  those 
 downspouts  are  and  you  capture  that 
 water  and  deliver  it  to  a  logical  place. 
 When  a  lot  of  the  projects  we  do,  the 
 logical  place  is  at  the  gutter  or  you 
 can  dump  it  out  close  to  the  street,  but 
 you  want  to  get  it  away  from  your  house. 
 The  other  thing  is  simple  gravity 
 drainage.  So  if  you  look  around  your 
 house,  we  want  to  try  to  figure  out 
 where  most  of  the  water  is  collecting 
 and  then  we  want  to  figure  out  how  it 
 can  just  with  gravity  flow  out  to  where 
 you  want  it  to  flow  to.  If  you're  trying 
 to  get  water  away  either  through 
 downspouts  or  just  by  [music]  drain 
 inlets,  you  want  to  use  solid  pipe.  Some 
 people  use  pipe  with  holes  in  it  with 
 the  idea  that  the  water  will  seep  into 
 the  soil  as  it  goes.  The  problem  with 
 that  is  if  you  have  plants  nearby,  the 
 roots  go  into  those  holes  and  end  up 
 plugging  up  the  drainage  pipes.  So 
 drainage  is  important  from  many 
 standpoints  in  the  landscape.  Poor 
 drainage  makes  plants  fail.  [music]  And 
 we've  already  established  the  value  of 
 trees.  Your  trees  aren't  going  to  grow 
 if  they're  constantly  have  saturated 
 roots.  And  probably  even  more  expensive 
 from  a  standpoint  of  losing  thousands  of 
 dollars  is  the  effect  on  your  house 
 where  you  get  mold  issues  and  you  get 
 degradation  issues  where  things  start  to 
 rot.  So,  what  we're  trying  to  do  is  keep 
 that  house  dry  all  the  way  around. 
 That's  how  you  can  save  thousands  of 
 dollars  in  maintenance  down  the  road.

 Aation  would  be  effective  if  you  have

 Thatch  builds  up  when  you  use  mostly 
 chemical  fertilizer  and  you  don't  have  a

 of  feeding  the  soil  directly  with

 there's  nothing  wrong  with  pruning  when

 either  encourage  growth  growth  or 
 discourage  growth.  Right  now  we've  just

 to  feed  more  growth.  And  [music]  so  if

 A  wrong  kind  of  cut  on  this  would  be  a

 This  branch,  I  want  to  make  a  little

 That's  a  thinning  cut  that  goes  all  the 
 way  back  to  where  that  branch  starts. 
 And  those  are  the  kind  of  cuts  we  want

 The  next  thing  is  a  layer  you  can  add  to 
 your  garden  which  will  completely  change 
 the  way  it  grows  in  a  positive  way.  I 
 will  tell  you  exactly  where  and  how  to 
 use  it.  Frequently  overlooked  is  the 
 importance  of  top  dressing  mulch.  It's 
 actually  a  mini  miracle.  What  top 
 dressing  mulch  does  for  your  soil  is 
 protect  it.  It  also  allows  it  to  break 
 down  and  enrich  it.  It  also  conserves 
 moisture.  And  all  of  these  things  go 
 into  making  it  ecologically  positive  and 
 an  important  part  of  growing  an 
 environmentally  friendly  landscape  and 
 garden.  This  is  not  necessarily 
 something  that  you  can  just  do  one  time. 
 You  need  to  refresh  it  and  renew  it 
 every  few  years.  It's  important  in  terms 
 of  the  health  of  your  soil  and  the 
 health  of  everything  you're  growing  in 
 your  garden.  Another  [clears throat]  big 
 benefit  of  it  is  weed  suppression.  And 
 it's  incredibly  effective,  minimizing 
 the  need  for  any  kinds  of  chemicals  and 
 such.  And  if  you  train  your  yard  that 
 way  over  time,  you  can  end  up  with  a 
 well-trained  yard  that  doesn't  have 
 weeds,  that  has  healthy  soil,  that 
 doesn't  need  a  lot  of  water  just  because 
 of  the  benefits  of  that  top  dress.  If 
 you  want  to  learn  about  all  kinds  of 
 gardening  and  landscaping  issues  and

 When  we  first  went  into  business  in 
 1979,  one  of  the  first  jobs  we  did,  the 
 builder  builds  the  house  and  we  work  out

 problems  with  water  intrusion  into  their 
 house.  Then  they  go  to  their  attorney

 the  landscape  contractor.  They  sue 
 everybody.  And  that  is  a  big  lesson  that 
 I  learned  in  that  very  first  job  is  to 
 pay  a  lot  of  attention  to  how  your  yard 
 drains  and  try  to  get  that  water  out. 
 When  I  first  moved,  the  yard  in  the  back

 common  way  to  drain  is  with  gravity.  You 
 grade  your  soil  properly  just  to  have  it

 The  problem  might  not  be  what  you  can 
 see,  but  what's  happening  underneath. 
 Here's  what  most  soil  is  missing  and  how 
 to  sustainably  fix  it.  Nothing  is  more 
 important  environmentally  in  a  garden 
 landscape  than  the  health  of  your  soil. 
 Healthy  soil  is  determined  by  life  in 
 the  soil  and  you  need  beneficial 
 bacteria,  beneficial  fungi,  good 
 prozzoa,  good  nematodes.  All  of  those 
 are  what  makes  your  soil  not  only 
 properly  feed  your  plants,  but  also  make 
 it  so  your  plants  don't  get  pests  and 
 diseases.  when  they  get  pests  and 
 diseases,  you  usually  respond  with 
 something  that  isn't  environmentally 
 friendly,  pesticides  and  such.  And  those 
 are  at  the  very  bottom  of  the  list  of 
 what  we  want  to  be  doing  in  our  garden. 
 The  best  way  to  make  sure  your  soil  has 
 beneficial  life  is  with  products  like 
 compost  and  earthworm  castings  or  our 
 concentrated  products  which  are 
 formulated  specifically  for  this 
 purpose.  We  want  soil  that's 
 environmentally  friendly,  ecologically 
 positive,  and  that  allows  you  to  garden 
 without  having  to  use  chemicals. 
 [music] 
 What  I'm  constantly  trying  to  do  is  use 
 things  that  improve  the  soil  because 
 it's  the  soil  that's  the  most  powerful 
 way  to  prevent  and  defeat  pests  and 
 diseases.  So,  we  don't  want  to  use 
 chemical  pesticides,  but  there's  a 
 number  of  organic  pesticides  that  are 
 tremendously  effective  at  building  the 
 soil  and  addressing  [music]  pests  and 
 diseases  at  the  same  time.  If  you're 
 building  the  soil  properly,  you  end  up 
 with  a  lot  of  good  neatodes.  And  good 
 [music]  neatodes  eat  grubs  or  the 
 beginning  forms  of  grubs.  And  so,  if  you 
 have  a  healthy  soil,  usually  you  won't 
 have  a  grub  problem.  Now,  to  get  there, 
 sometimes  it  takes  a  while  and  you  don't 
 want  to  put  up  with  grubs.  look  into 
 [music] 
 using  our  products  plus  the  use  of 
 beneficial  nematodes.  Some  other 
 products  that  are  natural  pesticides

 beneficial  bacteria  also  effective  on  a

 quickly.  There's  a  range  of  organic 
 solutions  that  build  soil  while  they

 Do  you  ever  look  at  your  garden  and 
 think,  "Oh  my  god,  how  do  I  make  this 
 look  better?"  You're  not  alone.  The 
 truth  is,  a  pretty  garden  is  not  just 
 about  expensive  plants  or  endless 
 maintenance.  If  you  follow  these 
 landscaping  principles,  I  guarantee 
 you'll  have  a  garden  that's  beautiful, 
 lowmaintenance,  and  an  actual  joy  to 
 spend  time  in.  What  if  your  version  of 
 pretty  looks  totally  different  than 
 everyone  else's?  That's  not  just  okay. 
 It's  kind  of  the  whole  point.  Probably 
 the  most  famous  home  garden  designer  is 
 Thomas  Church.  He  wrote  a  fantastic  book 
 called  Gardens  Are  for  People.  That 
 saying,  "Gardens  are  for  people  infers 
 that  gardens  are  to  meet  your  needs,  to 
 make  your  life  better."  And  so  if  we 
 focus  on  that,  making  your  life  better 
 in  your  own  garden,  then  you're  going  to 
 have  a  landscape  that  is  pretty  to  you 
 and  that  is  functional  for  you  and  that 
 meets  your  everyday  needs  and  improves 
 your  life  on  an  everyday  basis.  So 
 Thomas  Church's  points  are  to  create 
 spaces  that  you  can  conduct  everyday 
 activities  in  and  to  do  important  things 
 like  shade  your  house  and  grow  food.  So 
 in  our  work,  we  come  up  with  front 
 courtyards  all  the  time  that  people  can 
 use  beyond  what  they  ever  anticipated. 
 So  they  can  wait  for  a  ride  or  talk  to 
 their  neighbors.  Get  some  use  out  of  a 
 front  courtyard  rather  than  having  broad 
 expansive  lawn  that  you  never  use.  You 
 only  look  at  and  walk  through  to  get  to 
 the  front  door.  Do  you  think  your  garden 
 is  too  small  or  too  awkward  to  plan 
 properly?  Let  me  show  you  why  planning 
 might  be  the  most  powerful  tool  you 
 have.  It's  a  mistake  to  just  willy-nilly 
 go  into  your  landscape  and  start  making 
 changes.  You'll  regret  some  of  the 
 changes  you  made  a  year  ago.  This 
 process  of  thorough  planning,  analyzing 
 your  site  and  your  house  and  your  needs 
 and  everything  about  what  would  be 
 pretty  to  you  is  important.  and  then  to 
 record  it  some  way.  You  can  either  if 
 you  don't  feel  like  drawing  a  plan  to 
 scale,  you  can  do  it  in  writing  almost 
 like  diary  form,  but  you  can  be  very 
 precise  about  the  things  you  want  to 
 emphasize  and  and  what  your  goals  are 
 and  how  you  think  you  can  achieve  those 
 goals.  Or  you  can  hire  somebody  to  do  a 
 two-scale  drawing,  but  you  need  to 
 somehow  have  a  plan.  What  I  have  found 
 in  the  process  of  trying  to  do  designs 
 is  the  more  time  and  work  I  put  into 
 analyzing  the  site  and  describing  what 
 the  opportunities  and  constraints  are  of 
 the  site,  the  easier  it  is  to  end  up 
 with  something  that  addresses  my  needs. 
 And  in  addressing  my  needs,  it's  pretty. 
 Next  up  is  something  a  lot  of  people 
 tend  to  overlook  when  they  design  their 
 garden.  And  if  you  really  want  that  wow 
 effect,  this  will  help  a  lot.  Many  are 
 tempted  to  use  all  the  strengths  of 
 their  garden  all  in  one  view  where  you 
 walk  out  your  back  door  and  you  look  at 
 your  yard  and  you  see  everything  at 
 once.  And  I  submit  to  you  that  that's  a 
 mistake.  We'd  like  to  incorporate  a 
 little  mystery  into  our  gardens  where 
 you  look  at  a  certain  vantage  point  and 
 you  can't  see  everything.  Even  if  you've 
 got  a  great  view,  we  don't  have  nothing 
 in  front  of  the  view.  We  have  a  garden 
 that  encourages  you  to  walk  through  it 
 and  be  surprised  by  special  spaces  and 
 special  views  of  special  features.  What 
 we're  trying  to  do  is  incorporate 
 mystery  into  the  garden  design.  As  you 
 think  about  that  creatively,  think  about 
 how  you  can  design  something  where  you 
 don't  see  everything  at  once.  You  can 
 use  plant  material  or  shear  type  fencing 
 or  trelluses.  You  need  to  incorporate  a 
 little  bit  of  skill  to  create  this 
 mystery  in  a  way  that's  pleasing  and  not 
 like  you're  building  stockades  in  the 
 middle  of  your  yard  in  order  to  have 
 mystery.  Even  in  this  very  small  garden 
 that  we  did  with  Japanese  maples,  it's 
 very  skillfully  designed  in  a  way  where 
 the  clients  walk  out  their  back  door  and 
 see  kind  of  an  informal  hedge  and  a 
 walkway.  And  once  you  get  on  that 
 walkway,  you  turn  the  corner  and  and 
 there's  more  plantings  and  there's  a 
 bench  and  even  though  it's  very  tiny, 
 you  cannot  see  the  whole  garden  by  just 
 looking  out  the  back  door  and  it's  very 
 intriguing  and  it  gives  mystery  to  the 
 yard.  If  you've  ever  felt  lost  trying  to 
 figure  out  your  garden,  hit  subscribe.

 have  all  the  information  you'll  need  to

 The  material  and  the  shape  of  it  evokes

 architecture  and  our  own  style  of 
 garden.  No  amount  of  garden  gnomes  or 
 fairy  lights  can  save  sickly  plants.  So, 
 how  do  you  easily  get  that  lush  garden 
 look?  The  key  to  healthy,  lush  looking 
 plants  that  thrive  and  bloom  is  healthy 
 soil.  What  determines  healthy  soil  is 
 lively  soil  with  all  kinds  of  beneficial 
 microbiologies.  We're  going  to  engage 
 the  soil  food  web.  And  getting  that  soil 
 food  web  to  work  for  us  is  the  way  to 
 have  a  healthy  landscape.  The  easiest 
 way  to  make  your  soil  healthy,  full  of 
 life  is  either  with  our  products  or 
 compost,  compost  tea,  things  like 
 earthworm  castings.  They  all  feed  the 
 soil.  We  believe  in  soilbased  gardening. 
 So  when  you  have  healthy  soil,  it  will 
 naturally  feed  your  plants,  even  produce 
 its  own  nitrogen,  phosphorus,  and 
 potassium,  and  all  the  micronutrients 
 and  minerals.  It's  amazing  what  the 
 power  of  soil  is,  and  I  think 
 underappreciated.  One  of  the  things  uh 
 we'd  like  you  to  avoid  because  we  get  a 
 lot  of  questions  about  it.  We  want  to 
 address  plants  will  do  much  better 
 without  landscape  fabric.  The  process  of 
 feeding  soil  is  much  easier  to 
 accomplish  without  landscape  fabric 
 because  usually  our  products  and  most

 get  clogged  with  roots  or  sediment.  And 
 that  is  frequently  what  happens  to 
 landscape  fabrics.  Now,  what  if  I  told 
 you  your  garden  and  landscape  could  look 
 even  better  if  you  stopped  trying  to 
 overcontrol  it?  Let  me  explain.  How 
 about  if  we  get  away  from  clubbing  our

 We  want  pretty  for  20  years,  not  pretty 
 for  a  day.  Sometimes  all  it  takes  is  one 
 small  thing  to  pull  everything  together. 
 And  most  people  overlook  it.  So  we're 
 talking  about  focal  points.  One  or  two 
 or  three  well-placed  showstoppers  of 
 some  type.  Fountain  or  sculpture  or  a

 There's  lots  of  ways  to  create  focal 
 points.  The  whole  garden  design  needs  to 
 be  set  up  so  that  these  focal  points  are 
 an  important  part  of  the  design.  Color 
 can  make  or  break  a  garden.  Get  it  right 
 and  your  yard  turns  into  a  showstopper. 
 Get  it  completely  wrong  and  you'll  give 
 everyone  a  headache  maybe.  So,  this  can 
 be  a  sensitive  area  because  I  don't  like 
 to  infer  that  there's  only  one  or  two 
 ways  to  use  color.  It's  very  personal. 
 One  idea  is  to  try  to  figure  out  ways  of 
 having  color  throughout  the  year.  Or 
 maybe  some  people  want  it  to  be  smashing 
 in  the  spring.  Usually,  it's  hard  to  do 
 both.  You  need  to  determine  about  when 
 you  want  your  color  and  then  you  come  up 
 with  a  color  theme.  One  thing  we  like  to 
 use  when  we  use  lantana  is  to  use  white 
 and  purple  trailing  lantana  together. 
 It's  compelling.  It's  beautiful.  It 
 lasts  almost  all  summer.  There's  some 
 easy  things  to  do  that  make  the  use  of 
 color  very  impactful  and  those  are  to 
 mask  the  color  and  to  pick  you  know  one 
 two  or  three  colors  but  I  don't  want  to 
 infer  that  that's  the  only  way  to  design 
 landscapes  effectively.  When  I  run 
 across  really  talented  artistic  people 
 they're  able  to  kind  of  violate  every 
 general  rule  of  designing  with  color  and 
 still  have  things  look  fantastic.  So  you 
 can  be  creative.  Pretty  doesn't  have  to 
 mean  perfect.  When  you  design  with 
 intention  and  a  little  or  a  lot  of 
 imagination,  your  garden  can  become 
 something  that's  uniquely  you.  If  you 
 are  ready  to  go  deeper  into  planting 
 your  own  personal  oasis,  check  out  this 
 video  here.

 In  my  60  years  of  gardening  and  my  50th 
 year  as  a  landscape  professional,  I've 
 seen  many  people  make  big  mistakes  in 
 their  landscaping,  usually  [music]  with 
 far-reaching  consequences.  Today,  I  want 
 to  share  with  you  what  most  people,  even 
 professionals,  don't  know  about 
 landscaping.  And  at  the  end,  I'll  reveal 
 an  argument  that  I  have  to  this  day  with 
 other  landscape  professionals  and  why 
 that  might  be  [music]  a  big  mistake  for 
 your  garden.  Starting  with  the  very 
 essence  of  your  design,  there  is  a 
 tendency  to  press  and  try  to  be 
 creative.  And  if  you're  trying  to  be  too 
 creative  and  not  practical,  you  might 
 heir  on  the  side  of  coming  up  with  all 
 kinds  of  fancy  squiggly  little  lines  and 
 thinking  that's  how  to  make  it  look 
 fancy  and  and  interesting.  Quite  the 
 contrary,  the  idea  of  setting  up  your 
 circulation,  so  your  walkways,  your 
 pathways  based  on  use.  I'm  really  fond 
 of  that  idea  that  instead  of  racking 
 your  brain  trying  to  be  creative,  let's 
 rack  our  brains  trying  to  be  practical 
 and  functional  and  within  that  if  we 
 stick  to  bold  lines,  it  can  look 
 extremely  professional  and  be  very 
 useful  at  the  same  time.  So  this  idea  I 
 heard  many  years  ago  was  addressing  a 
 college  campus  where  when  they  made 
 additions  instead  of  putting  in  the 
 circulation  right  away  they  allowed  the 
 students  to  establish  the  circulation 
 where  they  could  see  the  patterns  that 
 were  being  used  because  these  were  the 
 best  fastest  ways  to  get  where  people 
 needed  to  get  and  then  build  the 
 circulation  around  that  using  either 
 straight  lines  or  broadspreading  curve 
 linear  lines.  You  might  have  a  personal 
 preference  for  curve  linear  versus 
 straight  lines.  And  that's  a  valid 
 preference.  That  could  be  how  you  decide 
 whether  you  want  curve  linear  or 
 straight  lines  just  based  on  what  you 
 like  the  look  of.  But  whichever  you 
 choose,  let's  be  direct.  Let's  be  bold. 
 Let's  be  simple  about  it.  There's 
 nothing  wrong  with  straight  lines.  Very 
 practical.  A  lot  of  times  straight  lines 
 tend  to  have  to  be  more  balanced. 
 Symmetrical,  not  necessarily,  but  many 
 times  that's  the  case.  So  if  you  choose 
 curve  linear  lines,  still  focus  on  the 
 simplicity.  So  I  wouldn't  necessarily 
 take  people  to  the  outer  reaches  of  your 
 garden  unless  you  have  an  area  back 
 there  you  want  people  to  be  in  and  then 
 it  can  be  appropriate  that  you  drop  off 
 part  of  the  circulation  drops  off  people 
 there.  The  other  thing  to  keep  in  mind 
 is  as  you  come  up  with  these  curbal 
 linear  lines,  maybe  the  apex  of  the 
 curve  is  a  view  point  from  your  house  or 
 a  viewpoint  from  somewhere  that  you  want 
 the  eye  directed. 
 Next  up,  you've  [music]  probably  been 
 told  you  should  use  compost  to  make  your 
 plants  green  and  healthy,  but  what  most 
 people  get  wrong  is  compost  isn't 
 fertilizer.  Let  me  explain  how  and  why 
 you  can  have  the  benefits  of  both.  You 
 expect  when  you  use  compost  that 
 everything  turns  green  and  healthy  in  a 
 week  or  two.  Well,  that's  not  the  case 
 because  compost  is  really  fertilizer  for 
 soil.  And  most  fertilizers  that  you  buy 
 at  garden  centers  and  nurseries  are 
 specifically  fertilizers  for  plants  that 
 don't  benefit  the  soil.  And  building  the 
 soil  through  compost  has  widespread  and 
 far-reaching  benefits  that  not  only 
 eventually  will  feed  plants  and  allow 
 your  soil  to  create  its  own  macro  and 
 micronutrients.  So  you  don't  need  to 
 apply  anything,  but  also  give  them 
 everything  they  need  in  a  fortifying  way 
 that  allows  soil  to  prevent  almost  every 
 pest  and  disease  there  is.  When  you're 
 using  compost,  you're  starting  a 
 long-term  program.  And  sometimes  that 
 long-term  program  doesn't  result  in  the 
 soil  immediately  producing  the 
 macronutrients  you  need,  for  instance, 
 to  keep  your  lawn  greener  than  the 
 Joneses  down  the  street.  It  might  be  a 
 year  or  two  before  you  notice  a 
 difference  in  the  vitality  and  color  of 
 your  lawn  after  beginning  to  use  compost 
 or  compost  tea.  So,  what  you  might  want 
 to  do  is  products  such  as  ours  and 
 things  like  earthworm  castings  and 
 compost  tea  and  compost  that  not  only 
 build  the  soil  and  do  it  on  a  long-term 
 basis,  but  they  also  can  feed  the  plants 
 at  the  same  time.  And  in  doing  this, 
 you've  got  the  best  of  both  worlds  that 
 act  as  fertilizer  for  the  soil  and 
 fertilizer  for  the  plants 
 simultaneously. 
 As  you  think  of  improving  your  landscape 
 in  your  garden,  most  of  us  want  one  or 
 more  trees,  either  for  shade, 
 aesthetics,  or  even  fruit.  And  once  you 
 find  the  tree  that  you  want  at  your 
 local  nursery,  you  probably  end  up  with 
 something  that  looks  like  this.  And  if 
 you  keep  it  that  way,  you'll  probably 
 end  up  with  something  that  hurts  your 
 tree  in  the  long  run.  So,  you  get  your 
 tree  from  the  nursery  with  this  steak 
 usually  tied  directly  to  it  and  that 
 really  isn't  good  for  the  tree.  The 
 nurseries  need  to  do  it  because  they 
 don't  want  to  sell  crooked  trees  and 
 straight  trees  are  desirable  and 
 preferred  in  most  cases.  But  do  you  know 
 why  that's  not  good  for  the  tree?  Well, 
 Chip  Valentino,  my  vice  president  in 
 charge  of  proper  staking,  is  a  big 
 student  of  this  issue.  And  what  happens 
 if  you  were  to  leave  that  stake  on  the 
 tree?  is  tied  directly  to  the  trunk.  It 
 inhibits  the  movement  of  the  tree.  And 
 it's  that  very  movement  that  allows 
 trees  to  develop  the  kind  of  tensil 
 strength  starting  at  the  bottom  right 
 around  the  soil  that  will  allow  them  to 
 stand  on  their  own  over  time.  Tensil 
 strength  is  when  the  trunk  is  wider  at 
 its  base  than  it  is  1,  2,  and  3,  and  4t 
 high.  And  that  really  is  our  goal.  We 
 don't  want  trees  that  are  permanently 
 staked.  We  want  trees  that  after  a  year 
 or  two,  all  stakes  can  be  removed.  So, 
 this  is  how  you  stake  it  to  have 
 movement  when  the  wind  blows.  We  have 
 two  stakes  and  then  we  have  two  flexible 
 ties.  Professional  staking  is  when  the 
 stakes  end  up  being  exactly  the  same 
 height.  And  the  ties,  in  my  opinion, 
 should  be  just  about  6  in  below  the  top 
 of  the  stakes.  And  the  way  you  determine 
 where  you  should  tie  is  you  grab  it  with 
 your  hand  and  wherever  you  can  hold  it 
 and  have  it  stand  up  straight,  you  go  6 
 in  above  that  and  that's  where  you  put 
 the  ties.  Then  if  you  want,  if  the  trunk 
 has  a  little  curve  in  it  or  something, 
 you  can  straighten  it  with  more  flexible 
 ties  down  lower.  There  is  some 
 controversy  even  among  professionals  is 
 how  you  should  orient  the  stakes.  I 
 really  believe  firmly  you  should  orient 
 the  stakes  so  that  the  prevailing  wind 
 direction  is  perpendicular  to  the 
 stakes.  So  not  where  the  wind  blows  into 
 one  of  the  stakes  but  stakes  on  either 
 side  of  the  tree  and  the  then  the  wind 
 comes  because  that  way  you  can  get  the 
 most  movement  and  that's  what  you  want. 
 This  is  a  big  issue  with  Chip.  And  if 
 you  want  to  learn  about  this  issue  and 
 many  other  important  issues  that  bug 
 Chip,  you  need  to  subscribe  to  our 
 channel.  Lastly,  this  bonus  point 
 [music]  is  something  Chip  and  I  have  had 
 heated  debates  with  landscape 
 professionals  for  years,  and  if  we 
 wanted  to  really  get  deep  into  it,  maybe 
 we'll  make  a  full  video  about  it.  So, 
 let  me  know  in  the  comments  if  you'd 
 like  me  to  do  that.  One  of  the  most 
 impactful  and  important  elements  you 
 design  in  your  landscape  and  your  garden 
 is  the  irrigation  system.  And  many  do  it 
 inefficiently  and  without  an 
 understanding  of  hydraulics.  Let  me 
 explain.  To  really  know  how  to  design  an 
 irrigation  system  is  to  understand 
 pressure.  Pressure  is  key.  Pressure  is 
 more  valuable  than  diamonds.  You'll  see 
 municipalities  and  even  people  going  to 
 great  expenses  to  put  in  booster  pumps, 
 which  are  expensive  and  many  cases  a 
 waste  of  money.  I'd  rather  do  it  without 
 booster  pumps,  but  understand 
 hydraulics.  I've  had  the  opportunity  to 
 interview  people  for  jobs.  And  my  key 
 question  is,  what  would  give  you  the 
 most  pressure  if  you  ended  a  pipe  that 
 you're  going  to  put  a  sprinkler  on  with 
 a  2-in  pipe  or  with  a  half  inch  pipe? 
 And  almost  all  professionals,  if  they 
 don't  really  understand  irrigation 
 design,  they  say,  "Oh,  we  want  to  make 
 it  smaller  at  the  end  to  increase  the 
 pressure.  So,  we'll  go  down  to  a/2  in  or 
 3/4  pipe.  We  get  more  pressure."  That  is 
 100%  wrong.  You  do  increase  velocity, 
 but  you  decrease  pressure.  And  the  only 
 reason  you  use  smaller  pipe  is  not  to 
 increase  pressure.  It's  to  save  money 
 because  the  smaller  pipe  is  a  lot  less 
 expensive  than  a  big  pipe.  So  what 
 irrigation  designers  that  know  what 
 they're  doing,  what  they  do  is  they 
 calculate  what's  the  smallest  pipe  I  can 
 put  throughout  the  system  that  will 
 carry  the  amount  of  water  that  needs  to 
 be  carried  that  will  have  minimal 
 pressure  loss  due  to  friction.  That's 
 what  you're  calculating  is  pressure  loss 
 due  to  friction.  So  how  does  that  apply 
 to  you  in  your  garden  and  landscapes?  We 
 have  a  rule.  We  never  use  half  inch  pipe 
 because  there's  not  a  big  difference  in 
 cost  between  half  inch  and  3/4  and  we're 
 safer  by  just  ending  everything  in 
 three/  quarter  pipe.  And  then  we  know 
 we've  got  plenty  big  pipe  for  most 
 sprinklers.  And  when  you're  talking  to 
 someone  you're  considering  hiring,  you 
 might  ask  them,  "How  do  you  maximize 
 pressure  at  the  end  of  every  line?" 
 Because  you  know  that  pressure  is  key  to 
 your  sprinklers  working  properly.  If 
 they  say,  "I  maximize  pressure  by 
 notching  down  the  size  of  the  pipe," 
 then  they  don't  really  understand  pipe 
 sizing  and  they  don't  really  understand 
 irrigation  hydraulics.  You'd  be  better 
 hiring  somebody  that  understands  that 
 the  pipe  size,  the  bigger  pipe  sizes 
 provide  you  more  pressure.  If  you  want 
 to  hear  more  tips  of  mine  garnered  from 
 60  years  of  experience  in  gardening  and 
 landscaping,  check  out  this  video. 
 >> [music]

 Rock  is  an  underrated  way  not  only  to 
 make  your  landscape  look  amazing,  but 
 also  to  add  a  lot  of  potential 
 functionality  to  your  garden.  And  I  love 
 functionality.  Today,  I  want  to  give  you 
 rock  landscaping  ideas  that  are 
 lowmaintenance  and  high  impact. 
 This  first  one,  you  don't  [music]  need 
 to  be  a  professional  landscaper  to  pull 
 off,  but  starting  with  this  will 
 instantly  make  your  landscape  feel  more 
 designed,  more  expensive,  and  have  more 
 curb  appeal.  There  was  a  big  trend  some 
 years  back  where  everyone  thought  they 
 had  to  have  boulders.  And  there  still 
 are  appropriate  places  to  use  settings 
 of  boulders,  especially  if  you're  trying 
 to  create  a  natural  type  landscape  with 
 mounds  and  to  remind  yourself  where 
 boulders  would  occur  in  nature.  Since 
 we're  trying  to  remind  ourselves  of 
 nature,  I  think  when  you  set  boulders, 
 you  should  use  principles  from  nature. 
 And  those  would  be  to  do  the  settings  in 
 odd  numbers  of  threes  and  fives.  Not  put 
 two  rocks  right  next  to  each  other. 
 Whatever  the  size  and  shape  of  the 
 boulder,  it  should  be  about  one/3 
 buried.  So  it  looks  like  it's  coming  out 
 of  the  soil,  not  laying  on  top  of  the 
 soil.  And  the  other  thing  is  use 
 settings  that  have  a  variety  of  boulder 
 shapes.  So,  like  if  you're  going  to  use 
 a  grouping  of  three,  you  could  put  one 
 flat  rock,  one  rounded  rock  that's  a 
 little  taller  and  maybe  one  upright 
 rock.  Those  make  interesting  and  very 
 natural  looking  settings,  especially 
 when  they're  buried  appropriately.  Hey, 
 it  just  came  to  us  at  the  Fresno  Chaffy 
 Zoo.  We  did  an  Asian  exhibit  with 
 boulders.  perfect  place  to  use  rock 
 outcroppings  because  we're  attempting  to 
 remind  ourselves  of  nature  and  we  used 
 these  principles.  [music]  That  was  a 
 pretty  bold  start.  But  what  if  I  told 
 you  there's  an  easy  way  to  add  structure 
 and  style  to  your  yard  without  pouring  a 
 single  drop  of  concrete?  So,  when  you 
 think  of  circulation  and  walkways,  you 
 might  immediately  think  of  concrete  or 
 asphalt  or  brick,  but  there's  a  much 
 less  expensive  and  environmentally 
 friendly  alternative  that  we  do  a  lot 
 of,  and  they  are  made  out  of  a 
 combination  of  decomposed  granite  and 
 gravel.  These  are  pathways  that  we've 
 done  many,  many  times  on  many  of  our 
 jobs  and  they  make  an  excellent 
 alternative  to  more  expensive  types  of 
 paving.  Depending  on  how  much  traffic  is 
 on  it,  if  a  lot  of  traffic's  on  it,  we 
 might  use  base  rock  first.  Sometimes  if 
 it's  just  pedestrian  and  minor  traffic, 
 we  might  just  use  decomposed  granite  for 
 2  to  3  in.  And  then  we  use  a  thin  layer 
 of  some  type  of  attractive  looking 
 gravel.  Could  be  3/8  inch  gravel.  It 
 could  be  3/4  in  gravel.  And  we  put  that 
 right  on  top  of  the  DG.  And  then  we  use 
 a  vibratory  compactor  and  we  press  it 
 into  the  decomposed  granite.  Usually 
 we'll  use  edging  to  define  it  and  to 
 keep  the  DG  and  the  rock  all  within  the 
 boundaries  that  we  want  it.  If  this 
 video  rocks,  please  hit  subscribe  and 
 don't  take  it  for  granted.  Many  people 
 think  this  next  option  looks  great  and 
 it  can  help  your  soil  and  plants. 
 Something  that  any  person  with  a  yard 
 should  prioritize  and  that  is  protecting 
 the  soil.  Now,  normally  when  you  think 
 of  protecting  the  soil  with  some  kind  of 
 top  dress,  you  think  of  some  type  of 
 wood-based  mulch  which  is  fantastic  for 
 soil.  But  there  is  another  option  and 
 that  is  rock  products.  And  the  rock 
 products  come  in  many  different  sizes 
 and  colors.  And  they  also  protect  the 
 soil  if  you  do  it  properly  and  amend  the 
 soil  properly  before  and  after.  We  like 
 to  use  our  John  and  Bob's  products  like 
 Blend.  What  I  think  is  important  if  you 
 use  uh  rock  products  as  a  mulch  is  not 
 to  make  it  real  thick.  Obviously  the 
 same  thing  as  with  wood  mulch.  You  don't 
 want  to  pile  the  rocks  up  around  the 
 base  of  the  plants.  It  can  be  just  an 
 inch  thick.  And  I  don't  mean  to  infer 
 that  if  you're  going  to  use  rock,  it  has 
 to  all  be  rock.  I  think  it's  an 
 interesting  look  to  have  certain  areas 
 where  you  think  wood  mulch  would  be 
 better,  maybe  because  of  the  type  of 
 plants  you're  growing,  and  then  areas 
 that  are  for  rock  mulch  only.  Many 
 people  associate  rock  mulch  with 
 landscape  fabric,  and  I  would  encourage 
 you  not  to  use  landscape  fabric  where 
 you  are  using  plants.  And  if  you're 
 using  rock  mulch  with  plants,  we  want 
 the  ability  of  products  like  ours  to 
 break  down  with  water  and  go  into  the 
 soil  profile.  With  landscape  fabric, 
 that  becomes  a  very  difficult 
 proposition.  And  many  times  the 
 landscape  fabric  over  time  gets  plugged 
 up  with  roots.  We  like  to  relegate  the 
 use  of  landscape  fabric  to  only  places 
 without  plants.  This  next  clever  rock 
 trick  turns  a  boring  and  potentially 
 problematic  part  of  your  property  into 
 something  functional  and  elegant.  We 
 went  over  the  walkway  out  of  gravel.  You 
 can  do  expanded  walkways  and  make  them 
 driveways.  And  we've  done  many.  And  if 
 you  use  a  decorative  rock,  they're 
 really  attractive.  And  we  make  them  very 
 sturdy.  You  can  see  this  one  here  at  my 
 house  where  we  used  uh  about  3  in  of  DG 
 and  then  we  pressed  this  very  attractive 
 rock  into  it.  We  have  an  example  here 
 where  we  just  used  DG  because  that's 
 what  the  homeowners  thought  they  wanted 
 and  they  started  having  problems  with 
 just  the  plain  DG.  For  one  thing,  it 
 tracked  and  every  time  it  got  wet  and 
 they  drove  over  it,  they  essentially 
 removed  some  of  the  DG  on  their  tires 
 and  so  it  got  to  be  less  and  less  and 
 then  water  from  rain  and  from  sprinklers 
 came  into  the  equation  and  went  into  low 
 spots  and  made  kind  of  a  muddy  mess.  So, 
 we  took  that  DG  that  was  there,  we 
 leveled  it  out  and  we  put  on  top  of  it 
 3/4  in  gravel  called  Sierra.  And  it  has 
 worked  fantastic.  Now  it's  a  clean, 
 permanent  paving,  very  inexpensive. 
 We're  not  stopping  at  functions.  The 
 next  rock  use  can  change  [music]  the 
 entire  vibe  of  your  garden.  And  we're 
 interested  in  changing  the  vibe.  This  is 
 an  interesting  landscape  that  the  owner 
 helped  us  design.  And  she  had  what 
 turned  out  to  be  this  great  idea.  We 
 used  edging  to  define  these  ground  cover 
 areas.  And  then  next  to  the  ground  cover 
 areas,  she  wanted  to  suggest  movement. 
 And  it  was  a  little  hard  to  picture  when 
 she  was  describing  it,  but  as  we  laid  it 
 out  over  time,  it  has  become  more  and 
 more  evident  that  it  works.  You  get  this 
 sense  of  movement  and  motion  without 
 anything  moving.  And  so  we  used  edging 
 and  then  we  used  a  3/8  inch  California 
 gold  rock  and  put  it  over  just  a  little 
 probably  a/  inch  of  um  decomposed 
 granite.  And  you  can  see  that  it's  very 
 effective.  There  are  other  ideas  where 
 you  can  use  rock  to  change  the  vibe  of  a 
 landscape.  One  of  them  that  I  like  to 
 use  is  different  types  of  rocks  and  set 
 them  into  decomposed  granite.  In  this 
 case  here,  we  used  uh  two  types  of  rock. 
 One  is  4  to  8  in  Noa  pebbles.  We  also 
 used  Mexican  cobble.  They're  smaller. 
 They're  dark  grayish  blackish  for  this 
 interesting  contrast  in  cobble  and  a 
 kind  of  a  a  wave  that  runs  through  it. 
 And  what  we're  trying  to  do  is  create 
 some  interest  right  up  next  to  the 
 house,  but  we're  trying  to  keep  the  area 
 dry.  We  don't  want  to  be  throwing  water 
 on  it.  And  there's  low  windows,  so  we 
 don't  want  water  to  splash  on  the 
 windows.  And  it  does  change  the  vibe  of 
 your  garden.  Really  unique  use  of  rock 
 and  boulders  that  we  ran  across  recently 
 was  actually  in  a  city  setting.  The  city 
 had  problems  with  homeless  people 
 congregating  and  trampling  plants  in  the

 an  interesting  design  using  rock  to 
 solve  all  their  problems.  They  used 
 crush  granite  as  you  can  see  here  around

 which  they  had  a  problem  with  that.  And 
 then  even  the  3/8  in  California  gold  is 
 used  as  a  ground  cover  mulch.  It's  rock, 
 rock  and  rock  solving  all  kinds  of 
 problems,  making  it  lowmaintenance, 
 difficult  to  access.  So  it's  an 
 interesting  use  of  design  concepts  with

 Do  you  want  a  garden  that's  stunning  and 
 also  good  for  our  planet?  These  six 
 eco-friendly  landscape  ideas  work  in  any 
 yard,  whether  big  or  small,  and  they'll 
 save  you  time  on  maintenance  while 
 making  your  plants  healthier,  too.  Let's 
 dig  in.  Almost  every  type  of  landscape 
 has  some  type  of  paving  or  walkway,  but 
 the  typical  kinds  like  brick,  concrete, 
 asphalt  cause  major  problems  with  your 
 storm  water  management.  These  two 
 surface  styles  address  the  problem  while 
 looking  very  attractive.  The  issues  of 
 imperous  paving  in  our  landscape  and 
 environment  is  a  major  issue  right  now 
 in  design  and  everyone  is  looking  for 
 ways  of  putting  in  paving  that's  pvious. 
 There's  a  lot  of  demand  for  that.  And 
 the  reason  they  want  pvious  paving  is 
 that  it  minimizes  the  need  for  big 
 drainage  basins  and  swailes  and  concrete 
 curbs.  Non-pervious  or  imperous  paving 
 is  paving  like  concrete  that  where  the 
 water  just  runs  off  and  goes  into  some 
 kind  of  storm  water  system  of  collecting 
 and  treating  water.  Pervious  means  that 
 it'll  filter  right  through  the  paving. 
 As  it's  going  through  the  paving,  it 
 mixes  with  microbes  and  these  products 
 that  are  pvious  to  actually  filter  the 
 water  and  as  it  gets  into  the 
 groundwater,  it's  clean  water.  One  very 
 common  one  that  we've  shown  you  in  other 
 videos  is  our  simple  garden  paths  idea 
 where  we  use  decomposed  granite  on  top 
 of  base  rock  and  then  we  cap  it  with  a 
 thin  layer  of  like  3/8  inch  rock  use  a 
 vibratory  compactor  to  press  it  into  the 
 DG  and  the  result  there  is  a  pvious  rock 
 path  that's  very  environmentally 
 friendly.  Another  way  to  approach  that, 
 we  use  this  unique  grout  in  between  the 
 flag  stone  called  perk  grout.  I'm 
 standing  right  now  on  the  perk  grout. 
 Let's  take  a  closer  look.  So,  it  doesn't 
 have  sand  in  it.  And  because  it  doesn't 
 have  sand  in  it,  it  has  a  lot  of  pores 
 in  it.  So,  it's  a  rough  finish,  and 
 that's  necessary  for  it  to  be  uh  pvious. 
 And  yet,  as  you  can  see,  it's  very  firm 
 and  hard  like  concrete.  Even  Toby  u 
 appreciates  it.  If  you  don't  believe  me, 
 let's  test  it  with  some  water.  Let's  see 
 if  it  goes  right  through.  Wow,  look  at 
 that.  This  isn't  even  puddling. 
 Look  at  that.  Just  goes  right  through 
 it. 
 Another  surface  in  landscapes  and 
 gardens  are  wood  decks,  and  they 
 actually  are  quite  ecologically 
 problematic.  Here's  what  we  can  use 
 instead.  Two  brands  of  products  that  can 
 be  used  on  decks  are  TX  and  Timberline. 
 Probably  the  two  most  popular.  95%  of 
 the  product  is  made  from  recycled 
 material.  Lots  of  plastic  bags  go  into 
 the  manufacturer  of  TX  and  Timberline, 
 which  is  neat  because  you  know  how 
 throwing  away  plastic  bags  is  a  problem. 
 There's  actually  a  good  use  for  it.  And 
 combined  with  wood  scraps,  a  product  is 
 made  that  replaces  wood.  And  wood 
 obviously  is  a  precious  resource.  And 
 also  wood  rots.  Trex  and  timberline 
 don't  rot.  And  also  wood  requires 
 refinishing  or  painting  or  sealing, 
 which  is  also  with  a  lot  of  products 
 that  aren't  environmentally  friendly.  So 
 TX  is  made  from  recycled  products.  It's 
 durable,  it's  strong,  it  lasts  much 
 longer  than  wood,  and  it  doesn't  require 
 refinishing  every  couple  of  years.  The 
 next  thing  is  a  layer  you  can  add  to 
 your  garden  which  will  completely  change 
 the  way  it  grows  in  a  positive  way.  I 
 will  tell  you  exactly  where  and  how  to 
 use  it.  Frequently  overlooked  is  the 
 importance  of  top  dressing  mulch.  It's 
 actually  a  mini  miracle.  What  top 
 dressing  mulch  does  for  your  soil  is 
 protect  it.  It  also  allows  it  to  break 
 down  and  enrich  it.  It  also  conserves 
 moisture.  And  all  of  these  things  go 
 into  making  it  ecologically  positive  and 
 an  important  part  of  growing  an 
 environmentally  friendly  landscape  and 
 garden.  This  is  not  necessarily 
 something  that  you  can  just  do  one  time. 
 You  need  to  refresh  it  and  renew  it 
 every  few  years.  It's  important  in  terms 
 of  the  health  of  your  soil  and  the 
 health  of  everything  you're  growing  in 
 your  garden.  Another  big  benefit  of  it 
 is  weed  suppression.  It's  incredibly 
 effective  minimizing  the  need  for  any 
 kinds  of  chemicals  and  such.  And  if  you 
 train  your  yard  that  way  over  time,  you 
 can  end  up  with  a  well-trained  yard  that 
 doesn't  have  weeds,  that  has  healthy 
 soil,  that  doesn't  need  a  lot  of  water 
 just  because  of  the  benefits  of  that  top 
 dress  mulch.  If  your  plants  are 
 struggling  and  maybe  sick,  the  problem 
 might  not  be  what  you  can  see,  but 
 what's  happening  underneath.  Here's  what 
 most  soil  is  missing  and  how  to 
 sustainably  fix  it.  Nothing  is  more 
 important  environmentally  in  a  garden 
 landscape  than  the  health  of  your  soil. 
 Healthy  soil  is  determined  by  life  in 
 the  soil.  And  you  need  beneficial 
 bacteria,  beneficial  fungi,  good 
 prozzoa,  good  neatodes.  All  of  those  are 
 what  makes  your  soil  not  only  properly 
 feed  your  plants,  but  also  make  it  so 
 your  plants  don't  get  pests  and 
 diseases.  when  they  get  pests  and 
 diseases,  you  usually  respond  with 
 something  that  isn't  environmentally 
 friendly,  pesticides  and  such,  and  those 
 are  at  the  very  bottom  of  the  list  of 
 what  we  want  to  be  doing  in  our  garden. 
 From  an  environmental  standpoint, 
 another  big  advantage  is  healthy  soil  is 
 a  carbon  sink.  It  doesn't  work  as  a 
 carbon  sink  if  the  soil  isn't  alive  with 
 all  the  beneficial  microbes  that  we  need 
 in  your  landscape  in  order  for  your 
 plants  to  do  their  best.  Also,  the  best 
 way  to  make  sure  your  soil  has 
 beneficial  life  is  with  products  like 
 compost  and  earthworm  castings  or  are 
 concentrated  products  which  are 
 formulated  specifically  for  this 
 purpose.  We  want  soil  that's 
 environmentally  friendly,  ecologically 
 positive,  and  that  allows  you  to  garden 
 without  having  to  use  chemicals. 
 Everyone  mows  their  lawn,  but  almost 
 nobody  does  it  like  this.  It's  faster, 
 greener,  and  it  gives  your  soil  and  your 
 lawn  a  big  boost.  And  that's  mulching 
 mowing.  Many,  many  mowers  have  that 
 mechanism  that  you  can  do  mulching 
 mowing  instead  of  mowing  and  collecting 
 the  grass  and  throwing  it  away.  This 
 way,  if  you're  using  a  mulching  mower, 
 you're  fertilizing  your  lawn  at  the  same 
 time  you're  mowing  it,  you're 
 fertilizing  your  soil  at  the  same  time 
 you're  mowing  it.  It's  kind  of  like 
 buying  our  products,  except  you  don't 
 have  to  buy  anything.  All  you  have  to  do 
 is  something  you  were  going  to  do 
 anyway,  and  that's  mow  your  lawn,  but 
 with  a  mulching  mower.  If  you're 
 unfamiliar  with  a  mulching  mower,  what 
 it  does  is  it  more  finely  cuts  up  the 
 lawn  so  that  it's  like  a  mulch.  You 
 don't  have  a  bag  or  anything.  There's 
 nothing  you  collect.  It  cuts  the  uh 
 grass  up  and  in  place  as  it's  mowing  it, 
 it  drops  it  right  back  down  onto  your 
 lawn.  What  you're  after  is  never  cutting 
 off  more  than  onethird  of  the  blade  of 
 the  height  of  the  blade.  So,  if  you  keep 
 your  lawn  3  in,  you  would  never  cut  off 
 more  than  1  in.  And  when  you're  cutting 
 off  less  than  1/3  of  the  total  length  of 
 the  blade,  that's  much  easier  to  mulch 
 because  this  mulching  mower  kind  of  cuts 
 it  up  into  a  product  that  decomposes 
 quickly  and  goes  back  into  the  soil.  And 
 there's  not  a  better  way  to  begin  on  the 
 process  of  building  the  soil  in  your 
 lawn  by  doing  mulching,  mowing.  Many 
 people  have  irrigation  systems  to  water 
 their  lawn  and  plants,  but  a  lot  of 
 these  systems  are  outdated,  inefficient, 
 and  unreliable.  Here's  how  to  make  sure 
 your  system  is  environmentally  and 
 ecologically  friendly.  So  the  first 
 thing  that's  a  big  part  of  an 
 echofriendly  irrigation  system  is  to  not 
 waste  water.  And  one  of  the  most 
 effective  systems  at  doing  that  is  a 
 drip  system  that  delivers  water  right  to 
 the  plant  and  doesn't  throw  water 
 everywhere  and  delivers  it  slowly  so  it 
 can  sink  in  and  not  evaporate,  which  is 
 what  happens  when  we  apply  a  lot  of 
 water  quickly.  it  makes  a  puddle  and 
 doesn't  even  ever  get  into  the  soil. 
 Secondly,  we  want  that  system  to  be  very 
 reliable  and  not  break.  When  it  breaks, 
 it  usually  wastes  water.  And  there's 
 ways  to  make  sure  it  does  that.  We  also 
 want  it  to  apply  water  evenly  and  be 
 able  to  control  the  water  so  that  you 
 don't  put  more  water  than  you  need  on 
 the  north  side  and  at  the  same  time 
 you're  applying  it  to  the  west  side  of 
 your  house.  So  you  need  to  separate  your 
 valve  so  that  you  can  apply  it  just  what 
 you  need.  A  mechanism  to  make  sure  that 
 you  apply  water  as  needed.  Many  have 
 come  on  the  market  recently.  I  like  the 
 ones  connected  to  weather  data.  So  it 
 analyzes  your  local  weather  and  based  on 
 the  kind  of  weather  you're  having.  If 
 it's  raining,  your  system  turns  off 
 automatically.  And  if  it's  100Â°,  you're 
 watering  more.  All  the  major 
 manufacturers  make  products  like  that. 
 Hunter,  Rainbird,  Toro.  There's  also 
 products  made  to  connect  your  system  to 
 soil  sensors.  I'm  less  fond  of  soil 
 sensors.  To  me,  they're  more  complicated 
 to  install  and  to  use,  but  it  is  a  way 
 to  have  a  system  that's  based  on  need 
 rather  than  you  just  guessing.  And  even 
 if  those  are  more  than  you  want  in  your 
 home  system,  just  focusing  on 
 efficiently  delivering  the  water  and 
 making  a  system  that  doesn't  break  and 
 is  reliable  and  making  even  watering  and 
 separating  the  zones  that  will  allow  you 
 to  have  an  environmentally  friendly 
 system.  If  you  would  like  to  see  one  of 
 these  eco-friendly  ideas  in  action, 
 check  out  our  construction  of  a  gravel 
 pathway.  It's  easier  than  you  think  and 
 your  garden  will  thank  you.

 I've  been  a  landscape  contractor  and 
 landscape  architect  for  46  years  now. 
 Wow.  And  I've  seen  just  about  every

 been  called  into  court  to  testify  as 
 expert  [music]  witnesses  about  mistakes. 
 And  Brendan  wants  me  to  admit  that  I've 
 made  a  mistake  or  two.  Today  I'm  sharing 
 the  11  most  common  and  most  horrific 
 landscaping  mistakes  that  I've  seen  so 
 that  you  can  hopefully  dodge  the 
 disasters.  People  think  they're  planting 
 properly  and  providing  a  suitable  home, 
 but  [music]  they  might  be  sentencing 
 their  plant  to  a  slow  death.  This  one  I 
 have  experienced  many  times  and  the  city 
 of  Fresno  has  responded  to  this  problem 
 by  coming  up  with  a  whole  policy  that 
 everyone  has  to  abide  by  in  order  to 
 avoid.  When  we  plant  a  tree  for  the  city 
 of  Fresno,  drilling  or  some  large 
 excavation  is  required  and  a  waiting 
 period  of  20  days  is  required.  Sounds  a 
 little  severe  to  have  to  wait  20  days  to 
 plant  the  tree,  but  that  reflects  the 
 seriousness  of  the  problem.  Settling  is 
 when  the  tree  sinks  below  the  grade, 
 almost  like  dropping  into  a  hole.  Then 
 whenever  it  rains  or  even  when  you 
 water,  water  collects  around  the  base  of 
 the  trunk.  And  there's  nothing  worse  for 
 a  tree  than  water  collecting  around  it. 
 When  you're  planting  your  own  trees  and 
 plants,  here's  how  you  avoid  settling. 
 First  of  all,  you  don't  necessarily  need 
 to  dig  it  deep.  You  could  just  dig  it 
 the  proper  depth  and  not  subject  to 
 settling  on  the  bottom.  If  you're 
 certain  you  don't  have  hard  compacted 
 soil,  but  think  you  have  hard  or 
 compacted  soil,  then  you  need  to  dig 
 down  and  get  past  that  layer  of 
 compaction.  Then  you  have  to  settle  it 
 completely.  Regardless  of  the  depth,  you 
 want  to  dig  the  hole  very  very  wide.  So 
 you  want  to  go  two  to  2  and  1/2  times 
 the  width  of  the  root  ball.  The  other 
 important  thing  which  is  not  well 
 understood  at  all  is  the  whole 
 preparation  or  the  back  fill  that  you 
 use.  All  soil  scientists  and  arborists 
 agree  that  it  isn't  beneficial  to  use  a 
 lot  of  bulk  amendment  in  the  back  fill 
 because  we  want  trees  to  root  out  into 
 their  native  soil.  We  usually  recommend 
 using  the  native  soil  so  we  don't  have  a 
 difference  in  texture.  So  you're  not 
 creating  what  is  sometimes  called  the 
 bathtub  effect  where  you've  got  a  hole 
 that  is  a  certain  texture  and  a  certain 
 quality  of  soil  and  then  you  create  an 
 interface  where  that  meets  up  with  the 
 native  soil  and  the  plants  won't  root 
 out  into  that.  The  next  one  as  I  drive 
 around  [music]  town  I  see  all  kinds  of 
 examples  of  this  is  very  personal.  In 
 fact,  frequently  I  clutch  my  heart  and 
 think  I  might  not  make  it.  When  you  see 
 the  kinds  of  violations  that  are  going 
 on,  I  can  see  examples  of  this  type  of 
 heading  back  inappropriately 
 many,  many  times.  That's  improper 
 pruning.  If  you  have  a  big  oak, 
 beautiful  oak  tree,  and  you  head  it 
 back,  you  really  cause  problems  for  the 
 tree  down  the  road  because  under  the 
 cuts  sprouts  all  kinds  of  new  growth. 
 And  that  new  growth,  if  it's  in  the 
 middle  of  a  big  branch,  is  very  weakly 
 attached.  And  so  now  it  becomes  a 
 dangerous  tree.  The  proper  way  to  prune 
 most  of  these  trees  is  with  thinning 
 cuts,  not  with  heading  back  cuts.  And 
 with  thinning  cuts,  you  allow  the  tree 
 to  display  its  beauty.  If  you're  doing 
 heading  back  cuts,  you're  creating  trees 
 that  all  look  alike.  They  just  look  like 
 a  big  blob  on  top  of  a  trunk.  they  won't 
 display  their  natural  form  and  they'll 
 we'll  be  weak.  We're  doing  a  disservice 
 to  the  trees  and  a  disservice  to  us.  So, 
 we  think  the  best  way  to  avoid  making 
 mistakes  is  to  hit  the  like  button  and 
 subscribe  to  our  channel.  I  can't  count 
 how  many  times  I've  seen  broken  pipes, 
 damaged  roofs,  damaged  foundations  from 
 poor  tree  choices.  Typical  lots  here  and 
 around  the  country  are  small  these  days. 
 And  small  lots  don't  have  a  lot  of

 He's  annoyed  by  even  the  discussion  of 
 it.  People  constantly  complain  about  too 
 many  weeds,  erosion,  having  to  water  too 
 much.  But  there's  one  simple  thing  that 
 you  can  do  that  solves  all  of  these 
 problems.  Almost  all  gardens  that  have 
 been  in  a  while  suffer  from  a  lack  of 
 top  dressing  mulch.  It's  really 
 important.  It's  really  good  for  soil. 
 It's  really  good  for  plants,  really  good 
 for  weed  control.  The  constant 
 replenishing  of  it,  you  can  actually

 And  yet,  if  you  tour  around  your  city

 pick  the  right  one,  it  looks  really 
 nice.  It  looks  better  than  your  soil. 
 So,  it  makes  it  look  like  you  have  a 
 rich  soil.  Having  an  irrigation  [music] 
 system  to  water  your  plants  and  lawn  can 
 be  a  huge  timesaver.  But  it  needs  to  be 
 designed  and  installed  properly  because 
 if  you  don't,  your  lawn  could  end  up 
 looking  like  this.  Especially  hot 
 climates  like  ours.  I  see  I  would  say 
 every  day  in  the  summer  problems  with 
 the  irrigation  system.  The  coverage 
 isn't  sufficient.  So  we're  after 
 head-to-head  coverage.  We  don't  have 
 head-to-head  coverage.  So  you  have  dry 
 spots.  It's  usually  the  reason  behind 
 excessive  weeds,  disease,  poor  growth  on 
 the  plants.  There's  one  other  irrigation 
 mistake  I  see  a  lot  of.  People  don't 
 realize  what  they're  doing  wrong  because 
 many  plants  are  thriving  and  some  are 
 dying.  It  might  be  tempting  to  just 
 throw  water  everywhere  if  you're  trying 
 to  irrigate  and  because  that  is 
 inexpensive  and  it's  the  simplest  way. 
 But  if  you're  growing  different  kinds  of 
 plants  in  different  exposures,  it  really 
 requires  that  you  separate  these  areas. 
 For  instance,  the  east  side  should  be 
 watered  differently  than  the  south  side 
 and  the  north  side  should  be  different 
 than  the  west  side  because  these  areas 
 get  different  amounts  of  sun  and  require 
 different  amounts  of  water  and  different 
 types  of  plants  require  different  kinds 
 of  water  and  raised  planters  are 
 different.  A  vegetable  garden  is 
 different.  So  all  of  this  requires  some 
 separation.  Separate  the  valves,  have  a 
 controller  that  you  can  apply  water  on 
 certain  days  for  certain  things.  And 
 that's  really  an  area  that  many  people 
 aren't  aware  of  when  they  start  out  with 
 an  irrigation  system.  If  [music]  you  fix 
 this  mistake,  you  can  fundamentally 
 transform  your  entire  garden.  This 
 lesson  I've  learned  from  years  of 
 working  in  the  industry  and  seeing  this 
 lesson  over  and  over  again.  It's  really 
 predominant  in  new  housing  subdivisions 
 because  builders  and  developers  hire

 and  they  get  bids.  So  they're  usually 
 interested  in  hiring  the  least  expensive

 And  so  you  see  many  many  landscapes

 level  everything,  put  saw  right  on  top 
 and  put  mulch  right  on  top,  but  no 
 consideration  at  all  is  given  to  soil

 And  the  soil  is  the  most  important  part 
 of  that  sod  thriving  and  those  plants 
 thriving.  Lack  of  consideration  for  soil 
 health  affects  all  kinds  of  things 
 including  poor  drainage  and  disease. 
 Lots  of  weed  growth,  trees  and  plants 
 not  rooting  out  into  the  native  soil,  so 
 they're  subject  to  blowing  over.  And 
 drainage  can  also  be  an  issue.  Often

 can  see  no  consideration  at  all  was 
 given  to  soil  preparation.  They  almost 
 always  include  fertilizer,  but 
 fertilizer  is  for  plants.  It's  not  for 
 soil.  For  soil,  we  need  products  that 
 encourage  life.  The  soil  can  be  improved

 complex  life  in  the  soil.  So  beneficial 
 bacteria,  fungi,  prozzoa,  good  neatodes 
 and  that's  really  the  essence  of  our

 maximize  and  our  penetrate  liquid 
 biotiller  particularly  good  for  heavy 
 soil  that  doesn't  drain  well  instead  of 
 our  products.  You  could  use  really  good 
 quality  compost  or  compost  tea.  [music] 
 This  style  of  planting  has  been  around

 and  over  again,  but  it  causes  problems

 If  you  want  a  beautiful  garden  in  fall, 
 winter,  and  spring,  there's  a  few 
 flowers  you  should  plant  right  now.  Chip 
 and  I  are  here  at  Green  Hills  Nursery, 
 and  we're  going  to  show  you  what  flowers 
 are  great  for  any  garden  and  landscape, 
 and  most  importantly,  which  ones  not  to 
 plant  in  the  fall  because  they  won't 
 survive  the  winter. 
 Okay,  Chip,  look  at  this.  First  thing  we 
 come  across  this  beautiful  denths  and 
 dianths  is  a  good  cool  season  annual. 
 You  can  plant  it  in  the  fall.  If  you  get 
 it  going  in  the  fall,  it'll  bloom  in  the 
 winter  and  the  early  spring.  Hot  summer 
 weather  makes  this  look  terrible. 
 Depending  how  hot  your  summer  is, 
 they'll  survive  through  the  summer  and 
 you  could  treat  it  as  a  perennial.  In 
 our  area,  it's  more  of  an  annual  because 
 it's  so  darn  hot.  So,  this  is  red 
 dianthis.  And  dianthis  comes  in  quite  a 
 few  uh  colors.  dark  purplish  that  we  saw 
 and  white  even.  You  can  plant  it  in  the 
 full  sun.  Doesn't  really  tolerate  shade 
 very  well.  The  color  you  choose  is 
 depending  on  your  design  style.  You 
 know,  you  can  mix  them  and  have  all 
 kinds  of  colors.  I  would  probably  pick 
 one  or  two  colors  just  because  I  like  to 
 do  massing  of  colors,  but  there's  not  a 
 right  way  and  a  wrong  way.  Most  of  these 
 plants  will  look  good  in  the  fall  and 
 the  winter.  Lavender  really  won't,  but 
 lavender  is  really  good  to  plant  now  if 
 you  want  it  to  just  start  blooming  like 
 crazy  in  the  spring,  early  spring.  It

 >> So,  if  you're  inspired  by  this  neat 
 zeroscape  garden,  here's  three  things 
 you  should  do  and  three  things  to  avoid. 
 With  a  zercape  garden,  one  important 
 thing  is  [music]  how  you  water  it. 
 Doesn't  make  sense  to  water  it  like  you 
 would  water  a  lawn.  So,  you  really  need 
 a  system  that  delivers  water  judiciously 
 and  directly.  Don't  keep  your  same 
 sprinkler  system  that  threw  water 
 everywhere  on  your  lawn.  Instead,  use 
 something  water  efficient  that  delivers 
 water  directly  to  the  plant.  It's  real 
 important  with  [music]  a  zeroscape 
 garden  to  maximize  the  health  of  your 
 soil  because  that  will  minimize  the 
 amount  of  water  that  you  need  and  that's 
 the  whole  point  of  a  zercape  garden  and 
 it  will  maximize  bloom  and  vitality. 
 You'll  be  doing  all  kinds  of  things  at 
 once.  So  here  we  used  our  John  and  Bob's 
 blend  and  our  penetrate  liquid 
 biotiller.  That's  a  great  way  to 
 maximize  the  health  of  your  soil.  In 
 this  case,  we're  in  somewhat  sandy  soil. 
 So,  it's  been  extremely  effective.  I 
 think  [music]  a  really  useful  and 
 important  part  of  a  Zercape  garden  is 
 let's  make  it  more  than  just  landscaping 
 to  look  at  from  the  street.  Let's  make 
 it  a  garden  we  can  walk  through,  a 
 garden  we  can  sit  in  and  talk  [snorts] 
 with  neighbors,  a  garden  that  uh  allows 
 us  to  use  it.  You  might  have  heard  me 
 say  before,  gardens  are  for  people.  And 
 that's  what  you  should  keep  in  mind  when 
 you're  designing  your  zeroscape  garden. 
 Don't  use  cheap  [music]  plastic  edging. 
 It  doesn't  hold  its  shape  well.  Even 
 though  it's  cheaper,  it's  not  worth  it 
 in  the  long  run.  It  produces  an  inferior 
 look  and  an  inferior  product.  So, 
 [music]  the  whole  point  of  a  zercape 
 garden  is  not  to  plant  things  that 
 require  a  lot  of  water.  Don't  plant 
 redwood  trees.  They  they  need  a  lot  of 
 water  in  the  summer.  Don't  plant  weeping 
 willows.  That's  the  most  water  thirsty 
 tree  you  could  plant.  So  don't  use 
 inappropriate  plants.  Focus  on  a  plant 
 pallet  made  up  of  California  natives  or 
 if  you're  not  in  California,  where 
 wherever  you're  native  to,  and 
 Mediterranean  uh  plants  that  uh  do  well 
 without  water  in  their  native  habitat. 
 Don't  overplant  the  garden.  And  don't 
 use  plants  that  dominate  the  garden 
 because  of  their  massive  size.  You  know, 
 if  you're  planting  a  zeroscape  garden,  I 
 don't  think  for  the  most  part  it  should 
 be  things  you  have  to  prune  and  and  make 
 into  shapes.  We  want  them  to  be  their 
 natural  form.  So,  in  order  to  allow 
 plants  to  just  grow  without  controlling 
 pruning,  you  need  to  be  very  conscious 
 of  not  picking  things  that  get  too  big 
 for  the  garden.  Look  at  what  it  looked 
 like  right  after  we  planted  it.  You 
 might  be  tempted  to  plant  more  plants 
 because  all  you  saw  was  rock,  but  we 
 didn't  want  a  rock  garden  here.  We 
 wanted  one  featuring  really  nice  plants. 
 So,  the  temptation  was  let's  plant  more. 
 Well,  we  didn't  plant  more  and  look  at 
 as  it's  growing.  And  this  is  just  after 
 a  few  months.  Let  them  grow.  Let  them  uh 
 attain  their  natural  form.  That  is  not 
 the  only  list  of  things  [music]  to  avoid

 chlorosis?  Iron  chlorosis  is  kind  of  a

 Does  your  lawn  look  tired  and  dreary  as 
 the  growing  season  comes  to  an  end?  Or 
 are  you  anticipating  your  lawn  turning 
 brown  as  soon  as  we  get  cold 
 temperatures?  Well,  listen  up.  Excuse 
 me,  Chip.  There's  a  technique  that  not 
 everybody  knows  that  will  make  your  lawn 
 go  from  looking  like  this  to  this. 
 We're  at  a  lawn  that  requires  this 
 special  technique  I've  been  telling  you 
 about.  And  I'm  going  to  allow  my  vice 
 president  in  charge  of  lawn  refurbishing 
 to  check  it  all  out.  Chip,  go  to  it.  To 
 achieve  this  goal  and  to  have  a  lawn 
 that  your  neighbors  will  be  jealous  of, 
 it's  important  that  we  understand  what 
 the  technique  is.  It's  called 
 overseating.  Let's  first  investigate  why 
 overseating  really  matters  for  your  lawn 
 health.  for  warm  season  grass  like  the 
 one  I'm  standing  on.  Then  that's  a 
 technique  to  keep  it  looking  good  in 
 fall  and  winter.  And  then  as  we  get  to 
 spring,  the  original  grass  will  start  to 
 take  over  and  you  mow  low  and  get  rid  of 
 the  overseed  grass.  Those  of  you  that 
 have  a  cool  season  grass,  it  is  a 
 technique  that  would  allow  your  lawn  to 
 look  great  all  year  round  because 
 sometimes  at  the  end  of  the  growing 
 season,  you  got  different  problems.  You 
 had  weeds,  you  had  fungus,  you  had  who 
 knows  what.  hopefully  none  of  those.  But 
 if  you  had  any  problems,  the  overseed  is 
 a  way  to  cure  all  of  that.  So,  what  is 
 the  easiest  way  to  overseed  it  for  the 
 fastest,  quickest  results?  Here's  what  I 
 do.  Mow  the  lawn  low  or  even  do  some 
 type  of  deatching,  but  something  that 
 will  allow  us  to  create  a  pretty  good 
 seedbed.  If  you  don't  prepare  the  lawn 
 properly  for  seed  is  it'll  just  sit  on 
 top  of  the  grass  and  doesn't  have 
 anything  to  germinate  in.  It  needs  a 
 little  bit  of  soil  or  a  little  bit  of  a 
 crevice  in  between  grass  blades.  Then 
 you  can  scatter  seed  by  hand.  For  cool 
 season  grass,  I  usually  spread  it  at 
 about  10  lbs  per  thousand.  That's  a  good 
 generous  rate.  And  you  need  to  be 
 careful  with  it  because  if  you  get  it  in 
 spots  where  you  don't  want  grass,  it'll 
 germinate  for  sure,  probably  better  than 
 in  your  lawn.  So  you  need  to  be  very 
 careful  if  you're  seating  it  by  hand. 
 And  you  also  need  to  try  to  make  it 
 even.  We  want  to  get  fairly  even 
 distribution  of  the  seed.  Warm  season 
 grass  has  a  completely  different  rate 
 and  you  wouldn't  do  that  in  the  fall. 
 Doesn't  come  up  in  the  fall.  You  would 
 be  doing  that  in  the  spring.  So  then  the 
 last  part,  really  important  part,  one  of 
 the  most  important  parts  is  watering. 
 And  one  thing  that  seems  to  be 
 misunderstood  is  you  water  completely 
 differently  than  you  would  normally 
 water  a  lawn.  We  don't  water  in  the 
 middle  of  the  night  or  early  in  the 
 morning.  We  wait  till  the  sun  comes  up 
 and  as  soon  as  it  starts  getting  warm, 
 we  start  watering  it  hopefully  more  than 
 once  a  day.  That's  the  formula  for  fast 
 germination,  warmth  and  moisture.  If  you 
 have  warmth  from  the  sun  and  then  you 
 can  keep  that  seed  moist,  it's  going  to 
 spring  up  really,  really  quickly.  So,  if 
 you  don't  have  an  irrigation  system  that 
 you  can  program  to  do  several  times  a 
 day,  you  need  to  figure  out  a  way  to  do 
 the  best  you  can,  which  would  be 
 watering  it  as  late  as  possible  in  the 
 morning.  We  don't  want  a  lot  of  water. 
 We  just  want  frequent  water  right  on  the 
 surface  to  keep  that  seed  moist  cuz  it's 
 on  the  surface.  Somewhere  in  the  7  to  21 
 day  period,  you'll  see  germination.  So, 
 those  are  the  basics.  Maybe  we  want  to 
 go  beyond  basic  and  get  this  grass  to 
 come  up  as  fast  as  possible  and  then  to 
 grow  as  green  and  full  of  vitality  as 
 possible.  I've  got  some  additional 
 tricks  to  tell  you  about  that  make  it  a 
 much  more  successful  overseed  planting. 
 I  sometimes  do  it  by  hand  on  very  small 
 jobs,  but  you  can  do  a  much  better  job 
 with  a  drop  spreader.  you  can  be  precise 
 with  the  seed  and  you  won't  have  grass 
 growing  where  you  don't  want  it,  which 
 is  very  typical  outcome  when  you  try  to 
 spread  it  by  hand.  And  then  when  you  use 
 the  drop  spreader,  it's  best  to  go  two 
 directions  and  that  way  you  don't  end  up 
 missing  a  spot.  If  you  want  to  rent  a 
 drop  spreader  for  seeding,  places  like 
 Home  Depot  have  them.  They're  not  real 
 expensive,  so  it  might  not  be  the 
 smartest  thing  to  rent  cuz  if  you  rented 
 it  two  or  three  times,  you  could  buy 
 one.  Although  I  frequently  try  not  to 
 use  it  because  on  a  big  job  it  can  be 
 expensive.  Some  kind  of  top  dress  mulch 
 right  over  the  seed.  And  that  top  dress 
 mulch  could  be  something  like  a 
 wood-based  compost.  On  the  West  Coast, 
 there's  a  product  called  a  mind.  But  all 
 over  the  country,  if  you  go  to  Lowe's 
 and  Home  Depot,  they  have  these 
 woodbased  fairly  fine  products  that  work 
 good  for  top  dressing.  And  you  don't 
 need  it  real  thick,  just  an  eighth  of  an 
 inch.  There's  two  ways  to  apply  it. 
 Screen  spreader,  which  you  can  rent  at 
 places  like  Home  Depot  usually.  And  the 
 screen  spreader  does  a  nice  job  of 
 spreading  it,  or  you  can  throw  it  on 
 with  a  shovel.  That  top  dress  mulch  is 
 great  for  conserving  moisture.  It's 
 great  for  creating  a  little  bit  of  heat. 
 So,  you  get  the  heat  and  the  moisture 
 with  a  top  dress  mulch.  And  if  you 
 recall,  those  are  the  two  keys  to  having 
 seed  that  germinates  real  quickly  and 
 thoroughly.  There  is  something  that 
 makes  a  huge  difference  on  seed 
 germination  speed  and  the  amount  of 
 seeds  that  germinate,  and  that  is  our 
 products.  A  lot  of  times  people  ask  me, 
 should  I  put  your  products  on  before  I 
 seed  or  after  I  seed?  Well,  right  on  top 
 of  the  seed.  You  put  that  seed  on,  then 
 you  put  on  the  blend  or  the  optimize, 
 whatever  you're  going  to  use,  depending 
 on  your  situation.  If  you're  going  to 
 use  a  top  dressing,  you  put  the  top 
 dress  on  and  then  you  spray  that 
 penetrate  liquid  biotiller  right  over 
 the  top  of  everything.  Both  penetrate 
 liquid  biotiller  and  blend  and  optimize 
 directly  benefit  seed.  Then  you  are 
 feeding  your  soil.  You're  feeding  the 
 new  seedlings  and  the  new  grass  all  at 
 the  same  time.  On  a  lawn  like  the  one 
 I'm  standing  on,  which  is  a  hybrid 
 bermita  lawn,  we're  going to  overseed  it 
 with  perennial  rye.  Perennial  rye  does 
 great.  It's  I  think  the  best  overseed 
 for  a  warm  season  grass.  If  you  have 
 some  shady  areas  where  the  grass  itself 
 isn't  doing  well  because  it  doesn't  get 
 enough  sun,  you  could  try  seeds  in  those 
 shady  areas  like  the  fine  fescues.  find 
 fescues  surprisingly  when  they  come  up 
 and  grow  look  a  little  bit  like  Bermuda 
 and  tolerate  much  more  shade.  And  in  a 
 warm  season  grass,  the  fine  fescues  are 
 probably  the  best  you  can  do  for  shade 
 tolerance.  Now,  if  you're  going  to 
 overseed  a  cool  season  grass,  then  I 
 usually  recommend  you  use  the  type  of 
 grass  you  want  your  lawn  to  be.  When  is 
 the  best  time  to  do  all  of  this?  Spring 
 or  fall?  If  you  do  it  in  the  fall,  when 
 in  the  fall?  The  answer  might  surprise 
 you.  In  my  opinion,  they're  both  good 
 times  to  overseed,  but  I  think  they're 
 they're  similar  because  you  can  get 
 similar  temperatures.  And  the 
 temperature  range  is  really  the  key  to 
 successful  germination.  And  some  of  that 
 might  also  depend  on  what  kind  of 
 overseating  you're  doing.  So,  if  you're 
 trying  to  get  warm  season  grass  to 
 germinate,  then  you  want  warm  weather. 
 Fall  isn't  your  deal  because  even  if  you 
 have  a  little  bit  of  warm  weather,  it 
 tails  off  quickly.  We  want  continuous 
 warm  weather  for  spring  overseeding  of 
 warm  seasoned  grass.  It  not  only  needs 
 to  germinate,  it  then  needs  to  grow  and 
 root.  If  you're  just  trying  to  refresh 
 and  regenerate  an  old  lawn  of  any  type, 
 fall  is  excellent  for  any  kind  of  cool 
 season  grass  because  the  seeds  will 
 germinate  great  and  do  well  in  mild 
 temperatures.  We  want  to  seed  say  a  cool 
 season  grass  when  highs  are  90  or  less 
 because  cool  season  grass  whether  it's 
 perennial  rye  or  fescue  or  bluegrass 
 they  don't  germinate  well  with  high 
 temperatures  70  to  90Â°  is  kind  of 
 perfect  for  germinating  cool  season 
 grass  for  fall  over  seeding.  Here  in  the 
 middle  of  California  we  are  starting 
 overseeding  right  now.  I'd  say  anytime 
 from  about  September  20  on  because  the 
 highs  have  cooled  down  really  all  the 
 way  to  about  November  20  cuz  we're  in  a 
 very  mild  area.  We  can  probably  overseed 
 depending  on  where  you  live.  Those  dates 
 will  vary  dramatically.  But  you  can  go 
 by  the,  you  know,  the  high  temperatures. 
 If  you  live  in  an  area  where  you  don't 
 have  temperatures  in  the  hundreds  or 
 even  above  90,  you  can  start  that  over 
 seating  pretty  much  anytime.  The  reason 
 we  don't  do  it  here  before  September 
 20th  is  because  it's  too  hot.  Seed 
 doesn't  come  up  good.  It'll  come  up  a 
 little  bit,  but  it  doesn't  come  up  at 
 the  rate  we  want.  So,  there's  one  more 
 thing  that's  really  important  for 
 ongoing  success  of  your  lawn.  I  run  into 
 some  disagreement  on  this,  but  I  believe 
 strongly  in  a  special  technique  after 
 germination  that  I'd  like  to  tell  you 
 about.  The  thing  I  like  to  do  that  I  do 
 find  some  disagreement  on,  but  I'm  a  big 
 believer  in  this.  No  matter  what  kind  of 
 lawn  you  plant,  try  to  mow  it  as  soon  as 
 possible.  Some  people  say,  "Oh,  I  want 
 to  make  sure  all  the  seeds  germinate.  I 
 want  it  to  get  tall.  I  want  I  don't  want 
 to  disturb  it."  Well,  I  don't  agree  with 
 that.  I  want  to  very  quickly  disturb  it. 
 Even  if  not  all  the  seeds  have 
 germinated,  as  soon  as  it's  tall  enough 
 to  mow  for  cool  season  grass,  you  know, 
 overseed,  that's  going  to  be  2  in  or  so. 
 Then  you  dry  out  the  lawn.  That's  an 
 important  step.  You're  doing  all  this 
 watering  now.  You  need  to  stop  that.  Dry 
 out  that  lawn.  And  as  soon  as  it's  firm 
 and  dry,  mow  it,  and  then  start  a  mowing 
 repetition  at  least  once  a  week.  Cuz 
 that  mowing  is  really  important  for  that 
 lawn  to  get  dense  and  thick  and  maybe 
 even  spread  a  little  bit,  to  out  compete 
 weeds,  and  to  just  be  healthy  and  full 
 of  vitality.  As  part  of  our  whole  soil 
 health  regimen,  right  after  that  first 
 mowing  to  make  the  lawn  as  green  as 
 possible,  we  do  one  application  of  our 
 nourish  bio  at  about  10  lbs  per 
 thousand.  Nourish  biosol  is  our  organic 
 fertilizer  and  soil  builder  made  from 
 the  bloom  of  cultured  soybean  meal  and 
 cotton  seed  meal.  And  that  combination 
 of  the  nourish  biool  mixed  with  the 
 prior  application  of  the  blend  and  the 
 penetrate  liquid  biotiller  is  a  really 
 thorough  feeding  of  your  soil  and  of 
 your  turf.  You're  ready  for  success.  The 
 fact  that  you  watch  this  video  all  the
