 Every  summer,  it's  the  same  story  here. 
 This  lawn  gets  brown  spots  no  matter  how 
 much  they  water  or  how  much  they 
 fertilize.  If  this  lawn  situation  sounds 
 familiar,  then  stick  around  and  find  out 
 how  we  brought  this  lawn  back  to  life. 
 Before  we  get  to  the  solution,  we  want 
 to  walk  around  with  you  and  make  sure  we 
 have  a  right  diagnosis  of  the  problem. 
 There  are  dry  spots.  If  we  feel  them,  it 
 is  just  bone  dry,  dusty  actually.  But 
 they  are  puzzled  because  there's  also 
 spots  that  appear  to  be  moist.  Like 
 right  next  to  this  dry  spot  seems  to  be 
 getting  water  with  the  irrigation 
 system.  It  is  moist.  The  owner's 
 conclusion  is  that  their  irrigation 
 system  is  a  bad  one  and  outdated. 
 Probably  a  40-year-old  irrigation  system 
 that's  been  modified  here  and  there.  All 
 different  kinds  of  heads.  you  know,  it's 
 not  a  state-of-the-art  irrigation 
 system.  In  addition  to  that,  this 
 juxtiposition  of  dry  spots  with  wet 
 spots  that  look  bad  give  you  an  idea. 
 There's  some  real  soil  deficiencies  also 
 that  I  think  is  giving  them  some  kind  of 
 fungal  disease  every  year.  They  have 
 tried  fungicides,  but  they  didn't  do 
 anything.  In  fact,  they  would  probably 
 make  it  a  little  worse.  Based  on 
 everything  I've  seen,  after  I've  walked 
 around  and  inspected  everything,  I've 
 concluded  the  problem  is  lack  of  water 
 in  some  spots  and  some  type  of  fungal 
 disease. 
 Let's  see  what  our  solutions  are  and  how 
 they  were  working  out.  We  did  end  up 
 completely  replacing  this  irrigation 
 system,  but  you  really  don't  have  to  go 
 that  far.  There  are  ways  to  improve  what 
 you  have.  Even  small  adjustments  can 
 make  a  big  difference  in  your  lawn  if 
 you  follow  these  three  simple  rules. 
 So,  this  job  is  all  new  pipe,  new 
 valves,  everything.  But  these  heads, 
 they're  called  MP  rotators.  They  could 
 just  retrofit  a  system  because  they  use 
 a  lot  less  water  than  most  and  they'll 
 allow  you  to  throw  water  just  as  far  or 
 farther.  So  have  better  coverage  even  as 
 a  retrofit.  If  you  don't  want  to  replace 
 everything,  you  could  just  replace  the 
 sprinkler  heads  and  sometimes  even  just 
 the  nozzles  cuz  it  comes  in  a  simple 
 nozzle.  What  we're  doing  with  the 
 irrigation  system  is  we're  making  sure 
 we  have  head-to-head  coverage  and  very 
 even  coverage.  Head-to-head  coverage  is 
 when  the  spray  of  one  sprinkler  goes  all 
 the  way  to  the  head  of  the  next 
 sprinkler.  So,  one  improvement  that  we 
 made  is  we  put  in  6-in  pop-ups.  And  you 
 can  see  how  they  pop  way  up  over  the 
 lawn.  You  know,  over  time,  the 
 sprinklers  kind  of  low.  If  they  only  pop 
 up  2,  three,  or  4  in,  the  blades  of  the 
 grass  will  block  them.  You're  given  a 
 certain  amount  of  pressure  at  your 
 house,  and  usually  you  can't  do  anything 
 about  that  unless  you  put  in  a  booster 
 pump,  and  you  don't  want  to  do  that  in 
 just  a  residence.  It's  more  trouble  than 
 it's  worth.  But  you  can  maximize  the 
 pressure  by  using  the  fewest  amount  of 
 gallons  per  minute.  A  head  like  the  MP 
 rotator  allows  you  to  use  small  amounts 
 of  water,  which  will  boost  your 
 pressure.  If  you're  using  25  gallons  a 
 minute  and  then  you  change  your  heads 
 and  now  you're  using  12  gallons  a 
 minute,  you'll  see  your  pressure  is  way, 
 way  better.  And  if  our  pressure  is  good, 
 then  our  coverage  is  more  even.  We  want 
 that  pressure  the  same  at  the  end  of  the 
 line  as  it  is  at  the  beginning  of  the 
 line.  And  that  is  also  easier  to 
 accomplish  if  we're  using  less  gallons. 
 If  you  have  a  choice,  we  want  you  to 
 water  real  early  in  the  morning  just 
 before  the  sun  comes  out  or  as  the  sun 
 is  coming  out.  That  makes  it  so  that  the 
 water  doesn't  sit  around  all  night, 
 which  is  something  that  causes  fungal 
 problems.  While  improving  your 
 irrigation  system  is  an  important  part 
 of  improving  your  lawn,  there's  an  even 
 more  vital  step.  And  no,  it's  not  more 
 fertilizer.  In  fact,  more  chemical 
 fertilizer  can  make  your  lawn  more 
 susceptible  to  fungal  disease.  So,  the 
 real  secret  is  to  build  soil  underneath 
 your  lawn  that  can  create  its  own 
 nitrogen,  phosphorus,  potassium,  and 
 other  minerals  and  nutrients.  When  you 
 have  good  fungi  and  good  microbiology, 
 it's  much  more  powerful  than  the  bad 
 fungus  that  causes  these  big  brown  areas 
 and  the  underperformance  of  lawn.  So, 
 how  do  you  feed  your  soil  in  order  to 
 make  it  healthy?  You  have  a  number  of 
 options.  You  can  use  compost.  You  can 
 use  compost  tea.  We  use  our  products 
 which  are  like  a  concentrated  compost. 
 Right  before  we  even  started  the 
 trenching,  I  applied  our  blend  at  about 
 20  lbs  per  thousand  and  I  sprayed  over 
 it  with  penetrate  liquid  biotiller  8  oz 
 per,000  square  ft.  Then  we  did  our  work 
 as  we  put  everything  back  together.  I 
 went  ahead  and  did  another  application 
 of  blend  at  20  lbs  per  thousand  and 
 penetrate  liquid  biotiller.  And  then 
 over  the  top  of  that,  I  did  do  about  six 
 pounds  per  thousand  of  our  nourished 
 bioalt.  Nourished  bio  is  really 
 excellent  for  lawns.  It's  our  organic 
 fertilizer  made  of  dried  mcelium.  Now, 
 it's  going  to  take  a  little  bit  of  time 
 for  soil  to  get  healthy.  We  think  the 
 process  has  started  here  and  you  can 
 begin  to  see  that  in  the  way  the  lawn 
 looks.  Once  you  have  your  soil  and  your 
 watering  right,  there's  a  simple  step 
 that  can  be  important  in  revitalizing 
 your  lawn  quickly.  So  since  we  had  so 
 much  bare  dirt  here  and  new  trenches  and 
 I  wanted  to  cover  them  up  right  away,  I 
 did  overseed  with  perennial  rye  right 
 after  we  covered  all  the  trenches  and 
 right  before  I  applied  our  last 
 applications  of  blend  and  penetrate 
 liquid  biotiller  and  nourish  biosol 
 perennial  rye  is  germinating  and  while 
 the  perennial  r  is  germinating  we're 
 getting  this  bermuda  to  look  a  little 
 healthier.  It's  starting  to  spread  and 
 that's  really  what  we  want  to  happen.  We 
 used  the  perennial  rye  as  kind  of  like  a 
 little  cover  crop  to  cover  bare  areas 
 while  we  get  the  Bermuda  to  thrive  and 
 prosper  through  healthier  soil.  It's

 disease,  and  it's  really  important. 
 Fungal  disease  is  prevalent  when  two 
 conditions  occur.  Heat  and  moisture. 
 First,  I'd  like  to  have  you  focus  on 
 watering  at  the  right  time.  We  don't 
 want  water  standing  around.  When  you 
 water  at  night,  it  stands  around  until 
 the  sun  comes  out.  A  better  strategy,  if 
 it's  possible,  is  to  water  right  when 
 the  sun  is  coming  up  or  right  before  the 
 sun  comes  up  because  you  put  on  all  the 
 water  that  you  need  and  then  the  sun 
 dries  it  up  and  it's  not  standing.  it's 
 not  stagnant.  Second,  make  sure  that  you 
 have  a  properly  functioning  irrigation 
 system.  And  that's  what  we're  working  on 
 here.  Every  year  for  the  last  five  or 
 six  years  in  the  summer,  they've  had 
 fungal  problems  and  they've  also  had  dry 
 problems.  That's  a  classic  example  of  an 
 irrigation  system  that  isn't  delivering 
 water  evenly.  And  that's  real  important 
 in  having  a  good  irrigation  system.  A 
 lot  of  times  that  happens  because  you 
 have  this  problem  area.  It's  always  dry 
 and  so  you  think  I  got  to  water  longer. 
 I  got  to  water  longer.  And  while  you're 
 watering  longer,  you  have  these  other 
 areas  that  do  cover  fine  and  now  they 
 get  too  much  water.  If  you're  watering 
 at  the  right  time  and  you  have  a  system 
 that  deliver  water  evenly,  you  have  the 
 ability  to  do  the  third  really  important 
 thing,  which  is  to  water  as  little  as 
 possible.  These  uneven  watering  systems 
 don't  allow  you  to  water  as  little  as 
 possible  because  you've  always  got  an 
 area  that  doesn't  get  much  water  and  you 
 got  to  leave  the  system  on  longer. 
 That's  our  overall  goal.  Water  as  little 
 as  possible  and  have  everything  healthy 
 and  looks  good.  So,  you  want  to  focus  on 
 proper  watering  and  on  feeding  your  soil 
 and  don't  fall  victim  to  this  trick  of 
 bio  advanced.  Bio-advanced  makes  it 
 sound  like  it's  a  biological  solution.

 This  yard  was  dramatically  impacted  by 
 their  dog,  Petey.  He  made  it  so  the  lawn 
 disappeared  because  of  digging.  The 
 owners  hired  us  to  make  it  a 
 lowmaintenance  dogproof  yard.  Join  us  on 
 this  video  and  we'll  show  you  some  ideas 
 of  how  you  can  dogproof  your  own  yard. 
 I'm  John  Valentino,  president  of  John 
 Bob's  Corporation.  This  is  Chip 
 Valentino,  who's  vice  president  in 
 charge  of  pet  landscaping.  He  has  a 
 GoPro  camera  today.  Stay  tuned  so  you 
 can  see  a  dog's  perspective.  While  I'm 
 not  usually  a  proponent  of  artificial 
 turf,  there  are  some  cases  where  it 
 makes  sense  and  it's  a  good  choice.  This 
 is  one  of  them.  With  a  regular  lawn,  you 
 can  get  pet  stains  in  the  summer.  Very, 
 very  common.  People  think  they  have 
 fungus,  but  it's  pet  urine  stains.  For 
 dog  urine,  you  rinse  it  off  as 
 frequently  as  you  want.  And  then  there 
 is  a  method  to  actually  once  a  year  or 
 so  give  it  a  better  cleaning.  You  can 
 keep  it  very  clean  without  a  lot  of 
 effort.  Also,  Pey,  the  dog  that  lives 
 here,  love  to  dig  in  the  lawn  pretty 
 much  destroying  it  constantly.  So,  the 
 benefits  of  artificial  turf  in  this  case 
 really  add  up.  Nice  shock  of  green. 
 Stays  clean  and  neat.  Dog  loves  it.  Dog 
 can't  dig  in  it.  Doesn't  need  mowing. 
 Doesn't  need  watering.  doesn't  need 
 fertilizing.  That  gets  a  lot  of  use.  I 
 like  that  if  you're  using  something  not 
 just  for  looks,  and  in  this  case,  the 
 dog  is  using  this  lawn  every  day.  One  of 
 the  biggest  downsides  of  artificial 
 turf,  especially  in  a  city  like  Fresno 
 that's  over  100Â°  many  days  in  the 
 summer,  is  the  heat.  It's  it's  a  hot 
 surface.  Some  people  choose  to  put  in 
 sprinklers.  On  a  hot  summer  day,  you  can 
 turn  on  the  sprinklers,  cool  it  off.  In 
 this  case,  we  have  these  big  shade 
 trees,  pacarpus,  sycamore.  So,  it's  a 
 cooler  yard  and  it's  a  shaded  yard.  And 
 in  the  absence  of  sun  beating  down  on 
 it,  the  heat  problem  isn't  as  big  a 
 factor.  So,  if  you  have  a  dog  and  you 
 want  a  lawn,  an  artificial  turf  is  a 
 simpler,  easier  thing  to  consider  that 
 might  work  good  for  you.  Does  your  dog 
 walk  into  your  house  with  muddy  paws  or 
 covered  in  dirt?  We  have  a  couple  of 
 tricks  to  solve  that  frustrating 
 reality.  One  of  the  important  things  we 
 did  is  instead  of  using  mulch  or  leaving 
 it  dirt  all  around  the  plants,  we  used  a 
 3/4  in  rock  that  makes  it  so  he  doesn't 
 seem  to  want  to  dig  in  the  rocks.  And 
 Petey  has  a  reputation  for  digging. 
 Chip,  the  angel  that  he  is,  doesn't  do 
 much  digging.  One  thing  that's  important 
 there  is  to  make  those  rocks  big  enough. 
 There's  a  lot  of  uh  gravel  or  rock  being 
 used  in  landscapes  that's  38  and  they 
 still  tend  to  dig  in  that.  But  if  you 
 can  make  it  3/4  and  bigger,  that  seems 
 to  not  prohibit  them  but  discourage  them 
 from  digging  in  it.  There's  lots  of 
 different  rocks  available.  This  is  an 
 attractive  one  called  Rainbow.  And  we 
 used  it  everywhere  we  could  use  it.  And 
 we  didn't  put  it  real  thick  because  if 
 you  don't  put  it  real  thick,  I  think 
 it's  good  for  soil,  good  for  the  plants 
 under  the  rock.  We  used  our  products  to 
 improve  that  soil  and  put  life  in  the 
 soil.  And  then  down  the  road  as  we  want 
 to  make  improvements  to  the  soil,  we  can 
 just  throw  it  on  top  of  the  rock  and 
 it'll  go  right  through  the  rock.  The 
 other  thing  is  I  don't  like  using  weed 
 fabric  under  the  rock  if  we  have  plants. 
 If  it's  in  a  area  where  you're  just 
 going  to  use  as  a  walk,  then  that's 
 fine.  We  did  use  a  little  mulch  here  at

 If  your  summer  garden  feels  like  a 
 full-time  job,  then  you're  probably 
 making  one  of  these  six  mistakes.  Hi, 
 I'm  John  Valentino  with  Chip  Valentino. 
 He's  my  vice  president  in  charge  of 
 keeping  summers  cool.  After  45  years  of 
 working  in  Fresno's  hot  climate,  we  have 
 learned  how  to  not  make  these  mistakes. 
 So,  when  things  get  hot,  instinctively 
 people  want  to  water  more.  While  that 
 might  be  appropriate  in  some  situations, 
 keep  in  mind  that  nothing  will  kill 
 plants  or  lawn  faster  than  high  heat  and 
 too  much  water.  When  the  soil  becomes 
 saturated,  it's  like  an  anorobic 
 condition  and  essentially  it  can't 
 breathe.  There's  no  exchange  of  air  and 
 water.  It's  just  stagnant.  That's 
 probably  most  prevalent  in  lawns  in  the 
 summers,  particularly  cool  season  grass 
 in  warm  season  climates.  You  need  to  try 
 to  have  the  water  be  very  even  and  not 
 get  water  logged  in  any  particular  spot. 
 If  you  have  standing  water  or  just 
 saturated  areas  of  the  soil  and  this 
 oppressive  heat,  that's  really  what 
 breeds  disease.  So,  we  want  to  stay  away 
 from  that.  In  planting  areas,  we're 
 trying  to  encourage  deep  rooting.  The 
 best  way  to  encourage  deep  rooting  is 
 you  do  watering  for  long  periods  of  time 
 as  long  as  the  water  is  being  absorbed, 
 but  you  don't  do  it  frequently.  You  give 
 the  soil  time  to  dry  out  in  between 
 waterings  to  where  even  the  top  is  just 
 barely  slightly  moist  or  the  top  might 
 even  feel  dry,  but  when  you  dig  down  an 
 inch  or  so,  there's  moisture.  and  then 
 that's  about  the  right  time  to  water 
 again.  So,  we've  discussed  the  pitfalls 
 of  overwatering,  but  don't  go  too  far 
 the  other  way.  There's  problems  there, 
 too.  Unfortunately,  underwatering  can 
 stress  your  plants,  leaving  them 
 vulnerable  to  pests  and  disease.  To 
 avoid  this  common  summer  mistake,  you'll 
 need  to  figure  out  if  you're  watering 
 the  right  amount.  So,  you  put  factors 
 together.  If  you  get  out  and  feel 
 around,  some  people  like  to  use  moisture 
 meters,  which  are  yeah,  probably  not 
 always  accurate,  but  interesting.  I 
 prefer  more  of  a  soil  probe  where  you 
 dig  down  and  and  sample  the  soil  at  an 
 inch  below  and  two  and  three  and  four 
 and  5  in  below  and  you  look  into  how 
 much  water  is  being  applied  or  the 
 weather  conditions.  Then  you  put  all  of 
 these  things  together  and  determine  if 
 it's  from  underwatering  or  an 
 overwatering.  There's  one  last  watering 
 mistake  to  discuss,  and  that's  watering 
 at  the  wrong  time.  If  you're  watering 
 the  right  amount  in  the  summer  heat,  but 
 you're  watering  at  the  wrong  time,  it 
 can  still  create  problems  in  your  lawn 
 and  your  shrubs.  The  textbook  right 
 time,  and  sometimes  we  can't  go  by  the 
 textbook,  but  the  perfect  time  to  water 
 is  very  early  in  the  morning,  right 
 before  the  sun  comes  out,  and  then 
 finish  the  watering  as  the  sun's  coming 
 out.  And  the  thinking  there  is  we're 
 applying  water,  there's  no  evaporation 
 due  to  sun  and  stuff  while  we're 
 applying  it.  So  that  gives  it  the 
 greatest  chance  to  soak  into  the  soil. 
 And  since  the  sun's  coming  out,  right, 
 when  we're  done,  water  won't  stand 
 around.  And  water  standing  around  is 
 what  creates  fungal  disease  in  the 
 summer.  You  can  be  aware  of  that  and  not 
 be  able  to  do  it.  Some  yards  and 
 especially  public  landscapes  that  are 
 big,  they  might  have  20  stations,  20 
 individual  valves  that  go  on  and  and 
 water  and  maybe  they  water  for  30 
 minutes  each.  So  that's  5  hours.  You  got 
 to  start  in  the  middle  of  the  night. 
 There's  no  way  to  get  everything  watered 
 before  the  sun  comes  up.  So  there  are, 
 you  know,  some  practical  exceptions  to 
 it.  But  if  you  keep  in  mind  the  ideal, 
 we'll  do  it  if  we  can  and  maybe  we'll  do 
 it  in  those  situations  that  are  most 
 sensitive  to  say  fungal  disease  like  the 
 lawn.  If  you  have  any  kinds  of  pest  and 
 disease  problems,  that's  one  thing  I'd 
 adjust  is  watering  time.  Are  you 
 skipping  mulch  in  your  garden?  That's 
 like  skipping  sunscreen  at  the  beach. 
 Not  using  mulch  is  a  gardening  mistake, 
 especially  in  the  summer,  that  can 
 create  more  work  for  you.  Here  are  all 
 the  reasons  why  you  want  to  regularly 
 mulch  your  garden.  And  I  might  not  even 
 be  able  to  list  them  all.  There's  so 
 many.  First  of  all,  it  protects  soil 
 from  the  sun.  The  soil  can  get  sunburn, 
 and  the  soil  can  be  damaged  by  the  sun 
 in  ways  that  impair  absorption.  A  good 
 mulch  does  conserve  moisture  in  a  way 
 that  really  helps  with  not  having  to 
 water  as  often  and  also  keeping  the  soil 
 moist  throughout  its  profile  rather  than 
 this  uneven  drying  out.  And  that's 
 really  good  for  plant  growth.  So 
 mulching  is  an  important  part  of 
 allowing  soil  to  function  like  it's 
 supposed  to  function  and  feed  plants 
 properly.  I  know  in  the  case  of  our 
 products  where  we're  trying  to  infuse 
 the  soil  with  life,  it's  amazing  how 
 much  better  the  products  seem  to  make 
 for  healthy  plants  when  there's  mulch 
 over  the  top.  How  much  faster  all  the 
 beneficial  stuff  that  we're  putting  in 
 the  soil  works  and  more  permanently.  So, 
 the  type  of  mulch  isn't  as  important  as 
 mulch.  There's  lots  of  different  things 
 that'll  work.  I  think  people  like  to 
 pick  the  ones  that  look  the  best.  And  I 
 I  like  that  criteria.  And  there  are  some 
 really  attractive,  you  know,  dark,  rich 
 looking  mulches  that  make  it  look  like 
 your  soil  is  dark  and  rich  looking.  And 
 plants  look  better  with  a  contrast.  I 
 don't  like  any  of  the  dyed  ones.  And  I 
 don't  think  the  dyes  are  good  for  soil. 
 But  any  natural  kind  of  mulch,  whether 
 it's  made  from  compost,  green  waste, 
 cedar,  Douglas  fur,  some  people  use 
 newspaper.  All  of  those  are  fine.  I 
 usually  either  use  shredded  cedar  or 
 walk-on  bark,  which  is  Douglas  fur.  The 
 frequency  applied  really  depends  on  how 
 thick  you've  put  it  and  how  well  it's 
 holding  up.  The  most  frequent  I  would 
 consider  mulching  is  once  a  year  and  the 
 least  is  once  every  five  years.  The 
 other  thing  is  if  you  have  a  planting 
 style  where  we're  planting  heavily  and 
 plants  are  covering  the  soil.  Well, 
 plants  can  protect  the  soil  just  like 
 mulch  can.  Then  the  mulch  isn't  as 
 important.  It's  when  we  have  big  blank 
 spaces  and  we're  trying  to  get  things  to 
 grow.  In  those  cases,  we  want  to  keep 
 that  soil  mulched.  Since  it's  hot, 
 feeding  your  plants  sounds  like  a  great 
 idea  until  you  overdo  it.  Putting  it  all 
 on  your  soil  in  the  summer  is  like 
 drinking  too  much  coffee.  Your  plants 
 get  stressed  and  they  crash  hard.  You 
 really  create  gardens  that  are  more 
 subject  to  pest  and  disease.  If  you're 
 overfertilizing,  you  know,  in  general, 
 we  don't  promote  using  synthetic 
 fertilizers  at  all,  but  there  might  be  a 
 time  and  place  for  them  here  and  there, 
 but  you  need  to  be  very  careful  with 
 them  because  they  can  really  burn  lawns 
 and  plants  easily  in  the  summer.  Organic 
 products  in  the  summer  are  fine. 
 Compost,  compost  tea,  even  thin  layers 
 of  earthworm  castings.  We  make  a  whole 
 line  of  products  that  work  really  well 
 in  the  summer  and  can't  burn.  We  finally 
 made  it  to  the  last  summer  mistake.  I 
 want  to  talk  about  gardener's  worst 
 enemy,  and  that  is  weeds.  If  you  don't 
 kick  them  out  early,  they'll  move  in, 
 start  a  family,  and  steal  all  your 
 nutrients.  If  you  avoid  this  mistake, 
 you'll  be  on  the  path  to  fewer  or  no 
 weeds.  So,  the  mistake  in  summer  weeds 
 is  not  having  a  strategy  built  around 
 early  intervention.  We're  training  our 
 landscape  and  our  gardens  to  not  have 
 weeds.  In  a  disciplined  garden,  we  need 
 to  have  a  strategy  about  how  we're  going 
 to  limit  weeds.  The  mulching  is  is  a 
 good  part  of  the  strategy.  We've  talked 
 about  that  already.  As  unpopular  this 
 is,  pulling  weeds  is  a  strategy  or  even 
 hoing  them  lightly  when  they're  small 
 makes  a  big  difference.  But  some  kind  of 
 strategy  where  we  are  addressing  them  as 
 soon  as  they  begin  to  develop.  People 
 are  always  asking  me  about  organic 
 methods  of  weed  control.  And  there  are 
 some  made  from  citrus  peels  and  made 
 from  vinegar  things  in  other  words  high 
 in  acid  that  in  the  summer  are  actually 
 pretty  darn  effective  because  they  burn 
 the  leaf.  But  with  those  products, 
 discipline  is  needed.  You  need  to  apply 
 them  frequently.  The  healthier  soil  you 
 have  with  a  complex  range  of  beneficial 
 soil  life  being  bacteria,  fungi, 
 prozzoa,  good  neatodes.  The  more  complex 
 life  you  have,  the  less  weed  pressures 
 there  are  healthy  soil.  And  then  this 
 early  intervention  strategy,  that's  how 
 to  train  your  garden  to  not  have  weeds.

 think  you  need  weed  and  feed  to  have  a 
 great  lawn. 
 You  actually  don't.  This  lawn  has  seen 
 zero  weed  and  feed,  and  it's  gorgeous. 
 In  fact,  using  it  might  do  more  harm 
 than  good  to  your  pets,  to  your  health, 
 and  to  your  lawn  itself.  I  will  break 
 down  why  not  using  weed  and  feed  is  the 
 best  thing  for  your  lawn,  what  you  can 
 use  instead,  and  stick  around  to  the 
 end.  I'll  share  three  free  ways  to  help 
 you  have  a  beautiful  lawn.  Broadcasting 
 weed  killer  while  we  broadcast 
 fertilizer.  It's  easy.  It's  simple,  but 
 it's  not  the  right  way  to  do  it.  I  would 
 prefer  to  carefully  select  a  fertilizer 
 and  then  carefully  select  a  weed  killer 
 based  on  what  weeded  it  is  and  in  a  way 
 that  we  can  limit  the  use  of  weed 
 killers.  The  idea  that  we're  taking  weed 
 killers  and  just  throwing  them  all  over 
 the  lawn  regardless  of  whether  there's 
 weeds  there  or  not,  that's  an  approach 
 that  doesn't  make  sense  to  me.  Why  put 
 weed  killer  on  healthy  lawn?  I'm  John 
 Valentino,  president  of  John  Bob's 
 Corporation.  This  is  Chip  Valentino, 
 vice  president  in  charge  of  healthy 
 turf.  It's  not  just  me  saying  this. 
 Local  governments  are  literally  asking 
 for  the  EPA  to  ban  the  weed  and  feed 
 ingredients  because  of  what  it  does  to 
 our  families,  our  pets,  and  our  drinking 
 water.  Most  weed  and  feeds  have  24D  and 
 some  other  chemicals  for  the  weed  killer 
 part.  24D  is  associated  with  cancer, 
 kidney  disease,  reproductive  problems. 
 Studies  have  indicated  that  dog  owners 
 who  use  24D  products,  their  dogs  are 
 twice  as  likely  to  develop  canine 
 malignant  lymphoma.  Weedfeed  ingredients 
 also  have  negative  impacts  on  beneficial 
 insects  and  honeybees.  So  with  all  these 
 negative  impacts  of  weed  and  feed  and 
 24D,  why  do  we  want  to  use  it  all  around 
 our  house?  What  can  you  use  instead? 
 There's  several  options  that  are  good 
 for  our  own  health  and  good  for  your 
 garden,  good  for  your  soil,  and  most 
 importantly  are  an  easier  way  to  garden 
 and  have  long-term  health  rather  than 
 this  approach  where  every  time  you  have 
 a  problem,  you're  putting  a  poison  on 
 it.  So,  the  first  step,  focus  on 
 building  the  soil.  And  if  you  can,  while 
 you're  doing  that,  ignore  the  weeds. 
 When  you  do  feed,  feed  with  something 
 that's  good  for  your  soil  because  that's 
 what  we're  trying  to  do  is  improve  our 
 soil  to  where  we  don't  have  weed 
 problems.  Products  like  compost  tea  or 
 even  compost,  earthworm  castings, 
 nourish  bio,  all  good  for  building  the 
 soil  in  a  way  that  makes  it  much  easier 
 to  grow  a  healthy  lawn.  After  say  6  to 
 12  months  of  this,  if  you  still  have 
 chronic  weed  problems,  what  are  those 
 weeds?  How  can  we  best  kill  those  weeds? 
 We  might  have  to  use  a  chemical  here  and 
 there,  but  we  would  use  a  chemical  just 
 for  spot  treatment  and  we  move  on.  We 
 don't  keep  using  it  every  year.  We've 
 talked  about  some  that  have  24D  and 
 dicama,  chemicals  like  that  that  have 
 proven  to  be  cancer-causing  and  not  the 
 type  of  thing  we  want  to  use  around  our 
 house.  But  there  are  a  couple  of 
 interesting  weed  killers.  I  still  use 
 them  as  a  last  resort  that  are  better. 
 One  is  called  Captain  Jack's  Lawnweed 
 Brew  ironbased.  When  I  look  at  the 
 ingredients,  I  like  the  ingredients  in 
 it.  It's  not  sold  in  California.  They 
 will  not  allow  its  use  in  California. 
 And  I  don't  know  why.  It  looks  like  a 
 pretty  good  alternative  to  things  that 
 appear  to  be  much  more  toxic  to  me.  The 
 other  one  is  tenacity.  The  chemical  used 
 in  it  has  no  link  to  causing  cancer.  If 
 we  need  to  rely  on  some  kind  of  chemical 
 weed  killer  in  lawn  that  does  not  kill 
 the  lawn,  tenacity  is  a  good  one  to  try. 
 Another  alternative  is  many  weeds  can  be 
 controlled  best  with  a  pre-emergent 
 herbicide,  which  if  you  time  them 
 perfectly,  they  can  kill  the  seeds 
 before  the  weed  develops.  And  if  you 
 understand  that  these  pre-emergent 
 herbicides  are  only  to  be  used  when 
 really  needed,  what  a  lot  of  companies 
 do  and  a  lot  of  people  that  care  for 
 their  lawn  is  they  use  pre-emergent 
 herbicide  just  by  the  calendar  every 
 year.  I  don't  like  that  approach.  Let's 
 just  use  it  one  time  if  we  need  it.  So, 
 you  want  to  improve  your  lawn.  Here  are 
 three  tips  that  will  not  cost  you 
 anything  that  you  can  focus  on  to  have  a 
 much  healthier  lawn.  Healthy  lawns  don't 
 usually  get  weeds  because  they're  so 
 dense  and  healthy  that  weeds  can't 
 compete.  Some  of  you  that  have 
 supplemental  irrigation  systems,  make 
 sure  they  work  right.  They  will  apply 
 water  evenly.  You  have  head-to-head 
 coverage.  Not  where  one  sprinkler  sprays 
 to  the  spray  of  another  sprinkler,  but 
 the  spray  of  one  sprinkler  actually 
 sprays  to  the  next  sprinkler.  That's 
 head-to-head  coverage. 
 One  thing  that  can  improve  weed 
 pressures  is  low  mowing,  but  you  only 
 want  to  do  low  mowing  if  you  have  a  lawn 
 that  does  well  with  low  mowing,  like 
 some  kind  of  Bermuda  or  improved 
 Bermuda.  If  you  have  tall  fescue  or 
 other  types  of  cool  season  grass,  you 
 can't  do  low  mowing,  but  you  can  do 
 regular  mowing.  Change  the  path  that 
 you're  mowing.  And  many,  many  weeds 
 can't  tolerate  constant  mowing.  Another 
 technique  that  I  like  to  use  as  a  way  of 
 refreshing  your  lawn  either  once  or 
 twice  a  year  and  is  effective  on  weed 
 control  because  then  we  guarantee  we 
 have  dense  stand  of  grass  is  overseeding 
 in  the  fall  or  in  the  spring.  Water 
 properly,  we  mow  properly,  we  overseed. 
 And  now  with  all  this  competition,  weeds 
 don't  know  where  to  go.  They're  lost. 
 they  can't  get  in  there  unless  you  do 
 one  of  those  improperly  and  you  develop 
 these  bare  areas  and  that's  when  weeds 
 come  in.  But  my  prediction  is  if  you're 
 feeding  your  soil,  if  you're  feeding 
 your  lawn  and  you're  overseeding  and 
 you're  watering  properly  and  you're 
 mowing  properly,  you're  not  going  to

 Everyone  wants  delicious,  sweet,  juicy 
 tomatoes,  but  most  of  us  aren't 
 successful  in  achieving  that  because 
 it's  not  just  about  water  and  sunshine. 
 I've  grown  tomatoes  for  about  20  years 
 now,  and  I  have  the  top  10  factors  to 
 allow  you  to  grow  the  sweetest,  most 
 delicious  tomatoes. 
 I  want  to  make  sure  you  hear  our  number 
 one  reason,  so  stick  around  to  the  end. 
 Number  10  is  pick  sweet  varieties.  This 
 is  the  factor  that  sets  the  tone  for 
 your  whole  season  of  tomato  growing.  So, 
 do  a  little  research  into  what's  the 
 characteristics  of  the  tomato  you're 
 going  to  plant.  The  absolute  sweetest 
 tomatoes  I've  ever  tasted  are  little 
 cherry  tomatoes,  which  tend  to  be  the 
 sweetest,  sunold,  and  sun  sugar.  When 
 you  taste  those,  you'll  know  what  makes 
 tomatoes  really  tasty,  and  that's  the 
 sugar  content.  We're  in  Oscar's  garden 
 here  in  Fresno,  California.  This  year 
 he's  growing  Whopper,  crimson  caramello, 
 and  beef  steak.  Number  nine,  6  to  eight 
 hours  of  full  sun.  Your  tomatoes  might 
 be  getting  sun,  but  do  they  get  enough 
 sun?  That's  really  an  important  factor 
 with  sweet  tomatoes.  So  6  to  8  hours  is 
 quite  a  bit.  Try  to  arrange  your 
 planting  spot  so  that  they'll  get  that 
 much.  Number  eight,  timing  is 
 everything.  You  need  to  plant  after  the 
 last  frost,  but  as  soon  as  possible.  The 
 sooner  you  can  plant  and  not  be  impacted 
 by  frost,  the  better.  March  15th  is 
 considered  kind  of  the  magic  date.  Oscar 
 planted  these  on  March  20th.  They're 
 doing  fantastic.  We  got  lots  of 
 tomatoes.  If  you  want  to  get  even  a 
 bigger  jump  on  it  than  waiting  till 
 March  15th  in  our  area,  you  can  plant 
 them  earlier,  but  you  need  to  use  frost 
 caps  or  something  so  that  you  protect 
 them  from  the  lows.  Number  seven, 
 improve  the  texture  and  the  tilth  of 
 your  soil.  so  that  you  have  excellent 
 drainage.  You're  much  more  subject  to 
 pests  and  diseases  if  you  have  standing 
 water  in  your  garden.  We  want  to  create 
 a  garden  where  water  percolates  through 
 your  soil  profile  easily  and  quickly.  If 
 you  need  more  information  on  how  to 
 accomplish  better  tilth  and  texture,  our 
 number  one  way  to  grow  sweet  tomatoes 
 addresses  this  issue  more  thoroughly. 
 Number  six,  maintain  consistent  but  not 
 constant  moisture.  Excess  moisture  makes 
 more  leaf  growth  and  less  tomato  growth. 
 That  upper  layer  of  soil  should  always 
 be  almost  dry  before  you  water  again. 
 Many  people  like  to  water  every  day. 
 Don't  do  that.  The  tomatoes  will  bear 
 better  and  be  much  sweeter  if  that  soil 
 is  allowed  to  drain  thoroughly.  Number 
 five,  use  sturdy  cages  or  trelluses  for 
 allseason  support.  That  all  season  is 
 important  because  they  tend  to  get  heavy 
 as  you  get  fruit  on  them  and  as  the 
 plants  get  big.  A  lot  of  the  varieties 
 of  tomato  plants  can  get  very  large.  If 
 you  just  shop  at  a  Home  Depot,  the  types 
 of  tomato  supports  they  sell  aren't 
 adequate  and  don't  work.  After  about  the 
 first  month,  the  tomatoes  are  knocking 
 over  your  support.  So  something  like 
 what  Oscar  has  done  here  with  these 
 cages  that  he  made  himself  and  then  he 
 makes  them  sturdy  with  these  lodgepole 
 stakes.  Number  four,  make  sure  your  soil 
 has  adequate  calcium.  We  like  to  look  at 
 about  a  7:1  ratio  between  calcium  and 
 magnesium.  The  only  way  you're  going  to 
 know  that  is  if  you  do  a  soil  test,  and 
 I'm  not  saying  you  have  to  do  a  soil 
 test.  If  you  have  some  problems  with 
 blossom  and  rot,  which  a  lot  of  tomato 
 growers  do,  it  is  because  the  plant 
 either  doesn't  have  enough  calcium 
 because  there's  not  enough  calcium  in 
 the  soil,  or  because  the  plant  isn't 
 uptaking  it.  Gypsum  is  one  way  to  apply 
 calcium  to  your  soil.  If  you  know  you 
 have  kind  of  a  slightly  low  pH,  you  can 
 use  lime.  And  if  you  want  to  lower  your 
 pH  a  little  and  add  calcium,  you  would 
 use  soil  sulfur.  Number  three,  for  how 
 to  grow  the  sweetest  tomatoes,  make  sure 
 you  allow  them  to  ripen  on  the  vine. 
 Ripe  tomatoes  have  a  beautiful  color 
 depending  on  what  varieties  you've 
 selected.  And  then  a  little  bit  of  give 
 in  the  tomato.  so  you  can  feel  them  on 
 the  vine. 
 Number  two,  cut  back  on  the  water  as  you 
 think  your  tomatoes  are  very  close  to 
 ripening.  The  idea  is  if  you  reduce  the 
 water  uptake,  but  the  plant  keeps 
 producing  glucose  and  fructose  and  the 
 tomato  keeps  producing  that  as  it 
 ripens,  then  those  are  more  concentrated 
 instead  of  diluted  by  water.  And  the 
 number  one  way  to  grow  the  sweetest 
 tomatoes.  Infuse  your  soil  with  life, 
 attractants  for  life,  and  food  for  life. 
 This  is  the  way  to  change  everything 
 about  your  soil  and  create  soil  that 
 feeds  tomatoes  and  plants  in  general  in 
 a  way  that  allows  them  to  grow  the  best 
 possible  fruit.  Products  like  compost, 
 earthworm  castings,  biochar,  ground 
 basaltt,  humic  acid,  fish  fertilizer  are 
 good  for  soil.  Our  products  utilize  a 
 lot  of  the  ingredients  I  just  listed  and 
 we  do  it  in  a  way  that's  convenient  and 
 easy  to  use.  That's  why  our  product 
 called  Blend  is  great  for  tomatoes  and 
 our  product  called  Penetrate  Liquid 
 Biotiller  is  fantastic  to  spray  over  say 
 once  a  month.  Oscar  on  these  plants 
 applies  penetrate  liquid  biotiller  twice 
 a  month.  Feels  that  it  really  helps  with 
 the  health  of  the  plant,  the  lack  of 
 pest  and  disease  and  the  sweetness  of 
 the  tomatoes.  So  that's  our  top  10  list 
 for  today  from  our  headquarters  in 
 Fresno,  California.  Which  of  the  top  10 
 lists  surprise  you?  Please  leave  it  in

 grower  or  tomato  lover,  share  this  video

 Many  of  you  see  brown  patches  on  your 
 lawn  in  the  summer  and  think  you  should 
 apply  a  fungicide.  Well,  many  of  these 
 problems  aren't  what  you  think.  After  46 
 years  of  dealing  with  these  problems 
 summer  after  summer  in  a  very  hot 
 climate,  I'm  going  to  show  you  a 
 non-chemical  way  to  make  your  lawns  look 
 green  without  brown 
 spots.  So,  let's  identify  what  is  the 
 cause  of  these  brown  spots.  The  first 
 issue  is  the  grass  type  that  you  grow. 
 Some  grass  types  are  much  less 
 susceptible  to  fungal  disease,  although 
 any  grass  type  can  get  it,  but  the  most 
 susceptible  is  when  you're  trying  to 
 grow  a  cool  season  grass.  So,  a  grass 
 that  stays  green  all  year  round  in  warm 
 climates,  especially  that  get  hot  and 
 humid  in  the  summer.  Before  you  plant 
 your  grass,  I'd  say  look  into  what  is 
 the  best  fit  for  your  climate.  Sometimes 
 that's  frustrating  for  people  because 
 the  best  fit  isn't  the  kind  of  grass 
 that  they  like  the  way  it  looks,  but 
 it's  really  a  big  factor  in  limiting 
 fungal  disease  and  limiting  brown  spots 
 in  your  lawn  in  the  summer.  If  your 
 lawn's  already  planted  and  you  have 
 these  terrible  problems,  there  are  other 
 ways  that  we  can  improve  it  so  you  can 
 either  get  rid  of  the  problems  or 
 minimize  them  dramatically.  The  first  is 
 how  you  water.  When  you  see  a  brown 
 spot,  it's  very  likely  it  could  be  a 
 watering  problem  and  it  could  be  a 
 fungal  problem  and  they're  hard  to 
 distinguish.  So,  you  need  to  put  in  some 
 other  information.  Think  about  what  kind 
 of  soil  you  have.  If  you  have  very  light 
 soil,  it's  probably  unlikely  that  it's 
 too  much  watering.  It's  more  likely  if 
 you  have  heavy  soil  where  you  have  these 
 brown  spots.  Dig  in  there.  Feel  that 
 soil.  See  if  the  soil  is  saturated  or 
 the  soil  is  extremely  dry.  Cuz  sometimes 
 just  by  looking,  I  can't  even  tell.  If 
 you  have  light  soil  and  you  dig  in  these 
 brown  areas  and  it's  extremely  dry  or 
 you  know  it  was  extremely  dry  recently, 
 then  you  need  to  look  at  watering  more. 
 And  if  you're  watering  every  day,  maybe 
 your  durations  or  your  the  amount  of 
 time  you're  watering  isn't  enough.  So 
 you  increase  the  amount  of  time  you're 
 watering.  Also,  the  quality  of  your 
 irrigation  system  is  a  big  factor.  You 
 need  to  make  it  apply  water  as  evenly  as 
 possible  so  you  don't  have  these  real

 disease.  We  don't  want  fungal  disease. 
 So,  we're  going  to  try  to  water  evenly 
 and  as  little  as  possible.  What  you 
 really  want  is  head-to-head  coverage. 
 Not  where  one  sprinkler  sprays  to  the 
 spray  of  another  sprinkler,  but  the 
 spray  of  one  sprinkler  actually  sprays 
 to  the  next  sprinkler.  That's 
 head-to-head  coverage.  If  the  problem  is 
 not  enough  water  and  you  correct  that

 instructions  on  how  to  plant  plants  is 
 to  dig  the  hole  and  back  fill  it  and 
 then  fill  it  with  water  for  a  week  or 
 two  before  you  plant  the  plants  to  let 
 everything  settle.  Not  bad  advice.  We 
 want  to  figure  out  a  way  to  plant  plants 
 where  they  stay  just  a  little  bit  high 
 above  the  surrounding  grade.  And  that 
 way  water  can  fall  off  of  the  stem  or 
 the  trunk  and  not  congregate  around  the 
 base  of  the  plant.  Another  problem  which 
 isn't  as  common  is  the  plant  could 
 completely  fall  apart.  You  know,  the 
 roots  just  come  apart  and  the  soil  fall 
 apart  because  of  desiccation  because  we 
 we  lost  too  many  roots.  you  could  have  a 
 plant  die  and  you  can  have  the  opposite 
 problem  where  a  plant  has  been  in  a 
 container  too  long  and  they're  circling 
 roots,  you  know,  growing  around  each 
 other  and  there's  not  a  lot  of  soil  in 
 there.  It's  like  a  potbound  plant.  You 
 don't  recognize  that  and  you  don't  in 
 the  process  of  planting  it  kind  of 
 separate  the  roots  and  encourage  it  to 
 root  out  into  the  native  soil.  That  can 
 also  cause  a  problem,  but  it  wouldn't  be 
 a  real  fast  death.  that  would  usually 
 take  a  while  for  the  roots  to  continue 
 to  circle  around  each  other  and 
 basically  strangle  itself.  You  can 
 usually  tell  by  performance  when  you're 
 talking  about  indoor  plants  if  they're 
 starting  to  be  rootbound.  It'll  look 
 like  they  need  fertilizer  if  they're  if 
 they're  rootbound  because  there's  not 
 much  soil  left  because  the  roots  have 
 taken  all  the  capacity  of  the 
 pot.  We're  moving  along  here  in  a  way 
 that  you're  not  going to  kill  your 
 plant.  But  there  still  is  another  thing 
 that  you  have  to  be  very  careful  about 
 and  that's  proper  or  improper  watering. 
 Here's  how  you  know  that  you  water 
 properly.  One  of  the  difficulties  in 
 watering  is  how  you  tell  if  they're  over 
 watered  or  underwatered  are  similar  in 
 terms  of  how  it  looks.  So  you  have  to  be 
 digging  into  the  soil  and  feeling  it  and 
 if  you  have  some  people  use  moisture 
 meters  if  you  have  something  like  that 
 you  try  to  determine  well  what's  the 
 likelihood  here  based  on  what  I'm  seeing 
 in  the  soil.  What  kind  of  soil 
 environment  is  it  in?  If  it's  in  a  very 
 light  soil,  then  I  would  suspect  first 
 underwatering.  If  it's  in  a  very  heavy 
 soil,  clay-like  soil,  I  would  first 
 suspect  overwatering.  I'd  say  lots  of 
 potted  plants  die  from  overwatering.  My 
 own  indoor  plants,  it's  surprising  how 
 little  I  water  them.  Not  even  once  a 
 month,  but  I  have  a  lot  of  big  pots. 
 With  potted  plants,  it's  important  that 
 the  pot  drain.  It's  best  to  have  a 
 drainage  hole  that  water  goes  right 
 through.  Frequently,  people  send  us 
 emails  wanting  me  to  tell  them  how  much 
 to  water.  It's  a  difficult  thing  to  say. 
 They're  probably  going  to  be  able  to 
 determine  that  better  than  me  because 
 they  can  watch  the  plant.  They  know  what 
 kind  of  soil  they  have.  They  have  a 
 certain  kind  of  irrigation  system  or 
 maybe  they  water  by  hand.  And  those 
 variables  are  impossible  for  me  to  know. 
 It's  mostly  trying  to  water  as  little  as 
 possible  and  watching  them  carefully  and 
 see  how  they  respond  and  then  looking 
 for  signs  that  they're  underwatered  and 
 then,  you  know,  kind  of  going  from 
 there.  Everything's  going  great  and  then 
 you  see  a  problem,  a  yellow  or  brown 
 leaf  or  a  pest,  and  you  think,  I  can 
 solve  that  easily.  I'm  going  to  spray  it 
 with  a  chemical.  Hold  on.  I  don't 
 recommend  that.  And  here's  why.  with 
 chemical  fertilizer  or  chemicals  to 
 fight  pest  and  disease.  These  are  one  of 
 the  most  common  ways  that  plants  are 
 damaged.  Maybe  the  instructions  aren't 
 followed  carefully  or  understood 
 completely  outside.  If  you  have  a  lot  of 
 hot  weather  and  without  water,  these 
 chemicals  can  be  very  toxic.  So,  our 
 recommendation  is  to  use  organic 
 products.  If  you  have  some  bug  or 
 something  on  your  plants  outside  or  even 
 inside,  the  first  step  is  to  just  wash 
 them  off  with  water.  We  want  to  start 
 with  the  least  toxic  things  and  we  would 
 almost  never  recommend  a  chemical. 
 There's  lots  of  organic  ways  to  address 
 pest  and  disease.  Back  to  healthy  soil 
 that  will  make  it  so  you  don't  get  pest 
 and  disease  or  very  rarely  do.  It's 
 incredible  the  natural  mechanisms  that 
 soil  have  if  it's  healthy  soil.  They  can 
 do  all  kinds  of  incredible  things, 
 including  making  its  own  natural 
 pesticide  in  a  way  that's  all  done 
 underneath  our  feet  without  us  having  to 
 apply  anything.  Sometimes  gardening  or 
 successful  gardening  is  a  little 
 mysterious.  Let's  say  you've  done 
 everything  right,  your  soil,  your 
 watering,  your  planting  techniques, 
 everything's  perfect,  and  yet  it's  still 
 not  thriving  or  blooming  like  you  want 
 it  to.  There  could  still  be  one  more 
 factor  outside  of  all  of  these  things 
 we've  just  talked  about.  What  we  might 
 call  environmental  stressors.  Maybe 
 you're  in  the  wrong  zone.  Your  highs  and 
 lows  aren't  proper  or  the  humidity  in 
 your  house  is  improper.  Or  you  could  be 
 just  too  hard-headed  like  me  and  try  to 
 grow  black  bamboo  inside  and  it  just 
 needs  to  be  outside  in  order  to  thrive. 
 My  wife  keeps  telling  me  it's  dead,  but 
 it's  not  dead.  It's  just  severely 
 underperforming.  If  I  just  came  and  I 
 saw  this  plant  look  like  this,  I'd  first 
 check  the  soil  and  try  to  determine  what 
 watering  regimen  was  being  used,  I 
 happen  to  know  it's  properly  moist.  It's 
 been  properly  watered.  It's  also  good

 Now,  I  also  know  because  I'm  the  one 
 that  planted  it  that  black  bamboo  don't 
 really  grow  inside.  This  one  I'm 
 attributing  to  the  fact  that  it  needs  to

 those  strategically  and  bend  them  over

 tape  is  my  favorite  thing  to  use  as  we 
 tie  these.  That's  pretty  good  for 
 branches.  If  you  use  anything  heavier 
 that  doesn't  have  give,  then  it  digs 
 into  the  branches.  After  we  tie  them, 
 then  we  go  into  pruning  where  we  clean 
 the  sides  up.  We  cling  even  the  inside 
 up  so  that  you  have  a  clear  path  to 
 walk,  a  clear  path  to  view.  On  the  side, 
 you  mostly  clear  it.  We  want  the  growth 
 over  the  arbor,  not  beyond  that.  The 
 pruning  will  be  very  logical  after  the 
 tying.  You're  going  to  prune  everything 
 that  doesn't  lend  itself  to  that  look  of 
 lemon  arbor.  It's  not  like  certain 
 branches  need  to  come  off.  It's  more 
 like  all  the  branches  can  be  considered 
 to  come  off.  Whatever  is  in  the  way  of 
 it  looking  like  the  type  of  arbor  you 
 want.  One  that  is  a  great  example  that 
 needs  to  be  pruned  is  like  right  here. 
 It's  in  our  way.  We  don't  want  this  to 
 continue  to  get  bigger.  So,  we  would  go

 of  spots  where  we  think  the  growth  is

 In  fact,  I  wouldn't  mind  if  there  were

 here.  I  like  lemons  down  low.  Easy  to

 future  after  the  crop,  maybe  we'll 
 consider  pruning  this  back.  The  only  way 
 to  get  a  healthy,  strong  growing,  pest 
 and  diseasefree  lemon  arbor  is  to 
 subscribe  to  our  YouTube  channel.  So  the 
 key  to  making  lemon  trees  grow  in  a  very 
 healthy  manner  is  soil.  The  way  you 
 maximize  the  health  of  plants  is  with  a 
 balance  of  nutrients.  That's 
 macronutrients,  micronutrients,  enzymes, 
 and  even  minerals.  And  the  best  way  to 
 get  a  balance  of  all  of  those  is  via  the 
 soil.  We  infused  the  soil  with  life, 
 beneficial  bacteria,  fungi,  good 
 prozzoa,  good  neatodes.  Let's  get  the 
 soil  as  healthy  as  possible.  Then  you 
 start  to  get  this  complex  life  that  is 
 key  to  allowing  your  plants  to  be  as 
 healthy  as  possible.  There's  several 
 ways  to  infuse  your  soil  with  life. 
 Earthworm  castings  are  a  good  way, 
 although  to  do  it  over  a  big  area  does 
 tend  to  be  expensive.  Compost  is  great. 
 Compost  tea  is  excellent.  What  we  used 
 was  very  convenient.  a  granular  product 
 we  call  blend  and  we  just  applied  it 
 topically  and  then  our  penetrate  liquid 
 biotiller  and  we  sprayed  right  over  the 
 top.  They  do  very  similar  things  to  what 
 compost  and  compost  tea  does  but  they  do 
 it  with  just  once  or  twice  a  year 
 applications.  Lemons  can  be  subject  to 
 pest  and  disease  like  mold,  rust,  aphid. 
 All  of  those  things  can  be  discouraged 
 by  healthy  soil.  Up  to  70%  of  pests 
 start  in  the  soil.  One  of  the  real  good 
 strategies  is  if  you  build  life  in  the 
 soil  that  those  pests  will  be  eradicated 
 before  they  become  pests  while  they're 
 still  in  the  soil.  Beneficial  microbes 
 eat  the  beginning  forms  of  pests.  If  you 
 rely  on  only  synthetic  fertilizer  to 
 feed  trees,  then  you  don't  have  the 
 infrastructure  in  the  soil  there  to 
 prevent  and  defeat  pest  and  disease.  If 
 you  do  run  into  some  pest  or  disease 
 problem,  use  some  kind  of  organic 
 product  that's  good  for  the  plant,  good 
 for 
 soil.  Wow,  this  got  some  nice  lemons 
 here,  huh?  Yeah,  there's  lots  of  good 
 varieties  of  lemons.  Lisbon  and  Eureka 
 are  probably  the  two  most  popular.  And 
 that  produces  a  classic  lemon.  And  then 
 there's  some  other  varieties.  There's 
 one  called  Ponderosa  that  produces 
 really  big  lemons.  Maybe  this  is 
 Ponderosa.  It  was  planted  before  we  got 
 here,  so  we're  not  sure  what  variety. 
 Lots  of  choices.  All  of  them  would  work 
 fine  to  make  a  lemon  arbor.  You  can 
 build  the  arbor  first,  which  seems  like 
 a  straightforward  way  to  do  it,  or  you 
 could  plant  the  lemons  first  and  not  let 
 them  grow  too  much  and  then  build  the 
 arbor.  Lemons  do  grow  pretty  fast.  So, 
 you  should  be  able  to  have  something 
 that  looks  a  little  bit  like  a  lemon 
 arbor  within  3  years.  We  hope  our  video 
 on  the  lemon  arbor  has  been  helpful.  If

 Is  this  plant  dead,  dormant,  sick, 
 underperforming?  A  polite  way  of  saying 
 you're  about  to  rip  it  out.  I'll  provide 
 five  telltale  signs  determining  if  your 
 plant  is  still  alive  and  then  what  you 
 can  do  to  revive 
 it.  So,  the  first  thing  I  did  because  I 
 could  tell  the  tips  were  dead  and  I  knew 
 that  Mexican  bird  of  paradise  was 
 sensitive  to  frost.  We  didn't  have  any 
 real  brutal  cold  weather,  but  we  did 
 have  cold  weather  during  the  frost.  And 
 so  the  first  thing  I  did  is  I  just  cut 
 off  the  tips  to  see  if  they  were  brown 
 or  green.  As  I  went  down  just  a  few 
 inches,  I  saw  they  were  green.  I  didn't 
 have  a  reluctance  to  cut  it  off  because 
 I  knew  it  was  dead  anyhow.  It  would  have 
 to  come  off  at  some  point.  Now,  if 
 you're  reluctant  to  cut  off  the  tips 
 because  you're  going  to  kind  of  screw  up 
 the  form  of  the  plant,  you  could  start 
 by  just,  you  know,  using  your  fingernail 
 and  seeing  if  just  under  the  outside 
 layer  it's  green  or  not.  And  this,  you 
 can  see  it's  very  much  alive.  The  color 
 of  that  is  life.  You  can  see  this  branch 
 here.  No  matter  where  I  cut,  it's  brown. 
 And  so,  if  all  of  them  were  like  that, 
 then  we  would  say  it's  dead.  But  it's 
 just  that  one.  And  so  we  cut  that  off. 
 And  this  the  same  thing.  We  cut  it  and 
 it's  brown  and  it's  brown.  This  part  we 
 can  just  take  off  because  it's  dead.  It 
 was  killed  by  frost.  I'm  John  Valentino,

 landscape  architect  and  a  landscape

 I'm  at  my  front  yard  here  in  Fresno, 
 California.  Most  of  the  plants  are  doing

 plants  that  are  a  little  bit 
 problematic.  When  I  see  a  plant  that  has 
 buds  starting  to  emerge,  you  can  really 
 stop  all  other  investigation.  You  know 
 it's  alive.  So  then  what  I  did  when  I 
 clipped  it  and  I  got  down  to  what  looked 
 like  green  wood  to  me,  then  I  looked  for 
 buds  all  along  the  part  that  I  left. 
 Everywhere  there's  an  inter  node,  you 
 can  see  a  bud  is  going  to  sprout.  We 
 celebrate  that  and  with  a  hallelujah. 
 This  thing  is  alive.  Just  needs  a  little 
 warmer  weather  and  it's  going  to  sprout 
 everywhere.  Which  makes  me  think  the 
 other  two  on  the  other  side  of  the 
 driveway.  Although  it's  harder  to  find 
 these  lively  buds,  if  I  look  real 
 carefully  at  them,  I  think  the  same 
 thing  is  going  to  happen.  But  for  some 
 reason,  they're  a  little  behind.  So,  a 
 dormant  plant  sometimes  can  be  mistaken 
 for  a  dead  plant.  And  there  wasn't  one 
 thing  wrong  with  it.  It's  just  that  it 
 got  impacted  by  below  its  comfort  level, 
 cold  weather,  and  that  made  it  go  into  a 
 deeper  dormcancy  than  I  would  have 
 thought.  Another  thing  you  can  check  for 
 is  the  flexibility  of  the  branches.  I 
 determined  that  those  tops  were  not 
 flexible  at  all.  When  I  cut  them  off, 
 they  were  very  brittle.  Then  when  you 
 get  into  the  part  that's  alive,  it  is 
 flexible.  So  maybe  in  a  tree  or  a  bigger 
 plant,  that  is  a  good  test.  You  test 
 flexibility  and  it'll  be  brittle  if  it's 
 dead.  And  then  you  can  cut  it  and  see 
 that  it's  green  if  it's  alive.  And  you 
 can  scratch  it  and  see  that  it's  green 
 if  it's  alive.  These  are  all  related  to 
 the  same  thing.  And  you  could  have 
 flexibility  with  no  leaves.  That  would 
 tell  you  that  it's  still  alive.  Then  you 
 look  for  buds.  You  scratch  it.  You  cut 
 here  and  there.  Put  all  those  together 
 and  you  got  a  failsafe  way  of 
 determining  if  it's  alive  or  not.  So  the 
 color  is  a  big  determinant.  And  you 
 probably  know  what  color  it's  supposed 
 to  be.  I  planted  about  65  shore  junipers

 plant  is  alive,  then  we  can  look  at  ways 
 of  bringing  it  strongly  back  to  life. 
 The  three  factors  we  look  at  are 
 environment,  water,  and  soil. 
 Environmental  is  exposure  and  general 
 highs  and  lows  of  the  climate  where 
 you're  planting  it.  The  soil  obviously 
 an  important  part  of  it.  We  want  that 
 soil  as  healthy  as  possible.  And  then 
 the  watering,  get  everything  properly 
 watered.  If  we  combine  environment  with 
 soil  with  water  and  get  all  of  those 
 optimal,  all  of  these  plants  that  we've 
 determined  are  alive  are  going  to  come 
 back  strong.  To  ensure  everything  was 
 going  to  do  great  in  spring,  I  started 
 in  the  fall  about  once  a  month  uh 
 applications  of  penetrate  liquid 
 biotiller  particularly  on  my 
 underperforming 
 plants  in  improve  that  life  in  the  soil. 
 Penetrate  has  all  kinds  of  beneficial 
 bacteria  and  food  for  bacteria.  These 
 that  are  underperforming  will  spray 
 right  over  the  top  and  around  the  root 
 zone.  This  is  a  very  very  gentle  way  to 
 encourage  plants.  It's  not  like  using  a 
 synthetic  uh  liquid  fertilizer.  This  has 
 things  like  kelp,  beneficial  bacteria, 
 um  humic  acid,  sapinin.  So,  it's  a  very 
 gentle  way  of  kind  of  encouraging  plants 
 to  do  their  best.  And  I  like  to  use  it 
 on  a  regular  basis  when  I'm  trying  to 
 get  a  landscape  started  and  get  the 
 plants  to  look  as  healthy  as  possible.  I 
 think  the  water  and  the  soil  are  just

 thinning  it  out  a  little  so  you  can  see 
 the  structure  of  it.  But  it  doesn't 
 really  get  much  taller  than  that  because 
 it  starts  weeping.  But  it  will  spread 
 quite  a  bit.  Next  to  that  is  another 
 tamokiama.  Then  I've  got  two  of  these 
 dwarf  ginkos  on  either  side  of  another 
 exit  and  entrance  in  and  out  of  the 
 garden.  And  the  sideyard,  we 
 transplanted  a  standard  iceberg  rose 
 with  two  colors  on  it  to  their  sideyard. 
 And  it's  a  really  a  charming  little 
 sideyard.  And  that  rose  is  doing  well. 
 Rose  trees  transplant  very  well. 
 Depending  on  your  environment,  but 
 especially  in  our  area  here  in  areas 
 that  have  hot  summers,  you  need  to  make 
 sure  you  have  the  right  exposure, 
 especially  these  finely  divided  ones 
 with  color.  They  tend  to  get  burned  in 
 the  summer  unless  you  can  provide  them 
 some  summer  shade.  The  other  thing  that 
 we  did  here  that  I  think  is  important 
 with  Japanese  maples  is  taking  great 
 care  to  infuse  the  back  fill  when  you  do 
 the  planting  with  beneficial 
 microbiological  life.  So  we  used  on 
 these  our  blend  which  is  optimize 
 maximize  nourish  biosol  and  we  also  use 
 penetrate  liquid  biotiller.  Even  though 
 the  soil  is  light  here,  it's  not  just 
 for  heavy  soil.  It  also  is  a  way  to 
 kickstart  building  life  in  the  soil, 
 which  you  need  to  do  in  sandy  soil  or 
 heavy  soil.  If  we  infuse  them  with  life, 
 they  will  take  hot  temperatures  much 
 more  successfully.  If  you'd  like  to  see 
 more  garden  walkthroughs  like  this, 
 please  subscribe  to  our  channel.  If  you 
 enjoyed  this  particular  walkthrough, 
 please  like  it  and  like  Chip.  Chip  will 
 appreciate  it.  Leave  a  comment  below 
 questions  you  might  have  about  Japanese 
 maples  or  osmanthus  fragrance  or  dwarf 
 ginkos  or  whatever  we  can  help  you  with. 
 Yeah,  it's  a  nice  little  yard.  We're 
 we're  really  eager  to  see  it  as  it 
 develops.  It  was  installed  some  30  years 
 ago.  The  landscape  architect  that  did

 the  plantings.  But  that's  it's  a  really 
 nice  circulation  pattern  in  a  small 
 garden.  It  gives  it  the  sense  of  more 
 space  than  is  actually  here.

 The  owners  have  shown  us  what  they  want 
 these  non-fruiting  olives  to  look  like. 
 I'm  going  to  show  you  how  to  prune  them 
 to  get  there.  These  techniques  that  I'm 
 going  to  show  you  will  apply  to  all 
 sizes  of  trees  and  actually  many  many 
 species  of  trees.  The  one  uh  distinction 
 here  is  fruing  trees  we'd  probably  use  a 
 little  different  methods,  but  these  are 
 non-fruiting  trees  and  I'm  going  to  show 
 you  how  to  get  there.  So,  the  tools 
 involved  are  very  simple  because  these 
 trees  aren't  that  big.  So,  I'm  going  to 
 use  some  what  is  traditionally  called 
 loppers.  Those  are  big  pruning  shears 
 that  you  operate  with  two  hands.  And 
 then  some  hand  pruning  shears.  A  lot  of 
 this  work  can  be  done  with  hand  pruning 
 shears  because  the  trees  have  only  been 
 in  the  ground  about  a  year  and  a  half.  I 
 only  recommend  sanitizing  pruning  shears 
 if  you're  pruning  trees  with  some  kind 
 of  disease.  In  this  case,  we  have 
 perfectly  healthy  trees.  No  need  to 
 worry  about  that.  Some  people  seem  to 
 think  it's  a  good  idea  to  put  some  kind 
 of  pruning  compound  on  the  larger  cuts. 
 Don't  do  it.  The  best  way  is  to  make 
 nice  straight  flat  cuts  and  allow  them 
 to  be  subject  to  the  air  and  good 
 circulation  and  they'll  heal  on  their 
 own.  The  very  lowest  small  branches  I'm 
 going  to  remove.  Some  are  on  the  inside, 
 some  are  on  the  outside.  So,  this  is 
 definitely  kind  of  gumming  up  the 
 inside.  It's  a  small  branch.  I  want  to 
 remove  all  of  these  small  branches  that 
 are  down  low  cuz  I'm  trying  to  raise  up 
 the  growth  in  general.  So,  I  take 
 these  and  by  getting  all  of  these  out, 
 it  allows  me  to  see  the  whole  thing  a 
 lot  better  and  then  I  can  get  in  easier 
 and  continue.  So,  this  is  another  small 
 one  that  for  one  thing,  it's  a  crossing 
 branch.  You  can  see  it's  crossing  with 
 this  main  branch  that  I'm  going  to  keep. 
 and  it's  goes  in  the 
 middle.  I'm  going  to  take  it  off.  The 
 one  thing  I  would  say  not  to  do  is  cut 
 branches  in  half.  That's  called  heading 
 back.  Instead  of  heading  back,  we're 
 going  to  be  thinning.  And  we're  going  to 
 be  removing  crossing  branches  and  we're 
 going  to  be  removing  a  lot  of  the 
 branches  in  the  center  to  let  in  light. 
 And  we're  going  to  be  directing  the 
 growth  up.  We  want  these  to  get  a  lot 
 taller.  So,  we're  going  to  pick  branches 
 that  are  going  up  and  remove  branches 
 that  are  going  to  the  side.  All  of  those 
 cuts  are  going  to  be  thinning  cuts  where 
 we  go  to  where  the  branch  originates  and 
 cuts  it  off  completely  instead  of  where 
 we  see  a  branch  we  don't  like  and  we  cut 
 it  in  half.  That's  a  heading  back  cut. 
 This  is  a  small  branch  crossing  this 
 major  branch.  We  don't  want  that.  We 
 don't  want  a  crossing  branch.  So,  we'll 
 take  this  small  one  out  as  close  to  its 
 origination.  Not  right  up  to  it.  You 
 leave  a  little  bit  and  it  heals  over, 
 but  pretty 
 close.  So,  some  of  these  I'm  just  trying 
 to  lift  up  the  growth.  The  other  thing 
 that  I  think  is  good  advice  is  to  go 
 relatively  slow  and  prune  less  than  you 
 think  you  want  to  prune  and  keep 
 stepping  back  and  looking  at  it  cuz  it's 
 easy  to  get  too  enthusiastic  and  then 
 you  go  back  and  you've  got  this 
 improperly  bare  tree.  It's  best  to  um 
 you  know  do  it  in  stages  and  keep 
 looking  at  it.  I  know  all  of  these  lower 
 ones  I  want  to  remove  because  I  want 
 this  tree  to  start  with  leaves  up  here 
 so  we  can  grow  these  upright  trees  that 
 give  us  room  to  get  by  when  we  walk  on 
 the  main  walk.  And  see  this  is  in  the 
 middle.  It's  crossing  with  that.  We 
 probably  take  them  both  out  and  they're 
 in  the  middle.  We  want  to  open  that  up  a 
 little.  This  one  looks  crossing  right. 
 So  we'll  come  over  here.  Take  it

 even  though  it  does  tend  to

 If  you  are  interested  in  Japanese 
 maples,  I'm  going  to  talk  about 
 different  sizes,  colors,  and  leaf  types. 
 We're  at  a  really  neat  little  garden  in 
 Fresno,  California,  and  we're  going  to 
 do  a  little  remodel  of  it.  You  can  hear 
 we  started  with  a  remodel.  One  of  the 
 things  I'm  going to  use  a  bunch  of 
 Japanese  maples.  Now,  you  might  say, 
 "This  garden  doesn't  look  big  enough  to 
 put  more  than  one  Japanese  maple  in." 
 That's  one  of  the  neat  things  about 
 Japanese  maples  is  they  come  in  all 
 sizes.  You  can  get  25  to  30  foot  and  you 
 can  get  dwarf  ones  that  only  get  3  to 
 four  to  5  ft  tall.  So,  the  size  of  them 
 really  does  vary.  Incredible  array  of 
 sizes.  I'd  say  the  smallest,  there  are 
 some  that  only  get  3  ft  tall.  I  haven't 
 seen  any  that  stay  smaller  than  that. 
 And  usually  they'll  show  a  range,  but 
 they  grow  very  slowly.  So,  it's  going  to 
 take  a  while  to  get  to  these  ultimate 
 sizes.  3  to  5t  tall.  That's  a  range  of 
 quite  a  few  varieties.  And  then  you  can 
 find  quite  a  few  varieties  that  are  5  to 
 8t  tall  and  quite  a  few  varieties  that 
 are  8  to  12  feet  tall.  And  a  lot  of  the 
 more  well-known  varieties  are  20  to  30 
 foot  trees.  So  there's  a  range  of  sizes. 
 For  this  project,  we're  going  to  pick 
 the  ones  that  are  in  the  3  to  7  ft 
 range.  A  couple  of  the  bigger  ones  maybe 
 will  rely  on  some  skillful  pruning  to 
 keep  them  down  to  5T  or  so.  They  vary  in 
 their  growth  habits,  but  the  three  main 
 are  upright,  spreading,  weeping,  and 
 everything  in  between  those.  Just  like 
 you  would  picture  a  weeping  willow, 
 that's  what  a  weeping  Japanese  maple  is. 
 The  leaves  are  in  three  categories.  A 
 maple  leaf,  and  then  one  what  we  might 
 call  a  ribbon  leaf.  than  one  that  seems 
 like  everybody  wants,  which  is  a  lace 
 leaf.  And  different  variations  of  those 
 three.  All  of  the  leaves  that  are  more 
 finely  divided  and  more  delicate  tend  to 
 be  more  sensitive  to  sun.  And  so  you 
 have  to  be  more  cognizant  of  its 
 exposure.  Make  sure  it  doesn't  get  much 
 or  any  afternoon  sun.  The  leaf  colors 
 are  tremendously  beautiful  and  varied. 
 You  can  find  orange,  purple,  red,  green, 
 yellow,  and  the  color  is  most  noticeable 
 in  the  spring  and  the  fall.  And  some 
 aren't  colored.  So,  they're  green  when 
 they  come  out  in  the  spring.  But  the 
 ones  that  are  colored  usually  don't  hold 
 their  color  through  the  middle  of  the 
 summer.  They'll  fade  just  because  of  the 
 heat  and  the  and  if  they  do  get  some 
 sun.  Another  fantastic  variation  with 
 Japanese  maples  is  the  bark.  Some  are 
 spectacular.  Probably  the  best  known.  is 
 one  called  sango  kaku  and  I  would  love 
 to  use  that  here  but  that's  25  ft 
 Japanese  maple  sango  kaku  has  this 
 beautiful  bark  adds  to  the  attraction  of 
 the  tree  even  in  the  winter  when  it 
 doesn't  have  any  leaves  it  has  this 
 vividly  colored 
 bark  maples  will  do  well  in  a  wide 
 variety  of  planting  zones  most  parts  of 
 the  country  can  grow  Japanese  maples 
 tend  to  like  slightly  moist  soil 
 particularly  ally  if  they  do  get  more 
 sun  than  they  should  get.  Uh  so  in  the 
 summer  if  you're  trying  to  keep  them 
 looking  good  and  not  burning,  then  you 
 want  to  make  sure  those  roots  stay 
 moist.  You  see  this  existing  boxwood 
 similar  to  how  you'd  water  boxwood.  You 
 learn  a  little  bit  about  their 
 characteristics  and  see  what  appeals  to 
 you  in  terms  of  leaf  color,  size  of  the 
 tree,  and  leaf  shape.  Check  out  what's 
 available  at  your  local  nurseries.  You 
 can  also  buy  small  ones  online,  getting 
 even  unusual  ones.  These  are  the 
 varieties  that  we  picked  for  this 
 garden  in  here.  We're  going  to  do  it 
 like  a  mini  arboritum.  They're  all  going 
 to  be  different,  dramatically  different 
 from  each  other.  And  that's  kind  of  the 
 the  theme  of  you  walk  through  and  you 
 see  this  little  mini  collection  of 
 Japanese  maples  that  all  have  different 
 colors  and  different  leaf  shapes. 
 There's  lots  of  varieties  of  Japanese 
 maple.  Maybe  you  have  a  favorite.  Let  us 
 know  about  it  in  the  comments.  Thanks 
 for  watching  and  keep  watching  if  you 
 want  to  see  this  garden  progress.  See 
 how  I  use  the  Japanese  maples  and  how  we 
 kind  of  spruce  this  up  and  plant  it.  And 
 if  you  like  this  video,  please  like  it 
 and  subscribe  to  us  what's  going  to  be  a 
 screen  of  Chameleia  Setsuga  up  against

 of  a  California  Native  that  isn't  native

 gardening  however  sometimes  people  would

 effective  on  apid  and  whitefly  it's  a

 penetrate  is  an  organic  liquid  bio 
 Tiller  that  breaks  up  very  hard  clay  and 
 compacted  soil  it  contains  bacteria  and 
 food  for  bacteria  actually  food  for  all 
 kinds  of  microbes  which  kickstarts  the 
 process  of  building  complex  life  and 
 it's  complex  life  that  is  the  key  to 
 healthy  soil  penetrate  liquid  bio  tiller 
 can  easily  be  used  using  a  hose  in 
 sprayer  or  a  backpack  sprayer  or  a  big 
 bucket  combine  both  bottles  the  bacteria 
 and  the  food  for  the  bacteria  with  water 
 water  is  simply  the  vehicle  we  use  to 
 apply  the  product  so  there's  nothing 
 specific  about  the  amount  of  water  we 
 list  an  amount  on  the  label  but  you  can 
 use  way  more  or  you  can  use  way  less  we 
 just  need  to  get  the  right  amount  of 
 product  on  in  the  right  amount  of  area 
 it  can  be  applied  directly  to  soil  or 
 over  Mulch  and  drenching  the  soil  isn't 
 necessary  a  light  application  is  all  you 
 need  in  the  case  of  the  big  bucket  you'd 
 be  drenching  specific  areas  a  helpful 
 tip  on  a  backpack  sprayer  take  off  the 
 nozzle  which  allows  it  to  flow  out  more 
 and  makes  the  application  a  lot  faster 
 if  possible  allow  it  to  rest  for  a  few 
 days  after  you  apply  it  this  allows  for 
 the  establishment  of  the  beneficial 
 bacteria  without  being  disturbed 
 penetrate  can  also  be  sprayed  on  plant 
 foliage  to  combat  pests  and  disease 
 penetrate  works  great  on  lawns  plants  of 
 all  kinds  and  soil  of  all  kinds  the  name 
 infers  it's  only  for  heavy  soil  but  it's 
 great  for  sandy  soil  also  penetrate  and 
 blend  can  be  used  to  refresh  Planters 
 and  containers  which  makes  it  so  you'll 
 never  have  to  change  your  soil  you  can 
 even  grow  tomatoes  year  after  year  in 
 the  same  soil  if  you  use  penetrate  and 
 blend  together  on  an  annual  basis 
 penetrate  comes  in  an  8  o  and  a  32  o 
 size  8  oz  treats  about  1,000  squ  ft  32 
 oz  treats  about  4,000  square  ft  that's 
 what  I'm  holding  right  right  here  I 
 usually  do  General  applications  over 
 broad  areas  if  there's  specific  plants 
 or  areas  of  the  garden  that  need  more 
 specific  attention  then  I'll  concentrate 
 the  application  in  those  areas  a  helpful 
 tip  apply  Blend  or  any  of  our  dry 
 products  and  then  spray  penetrate  liquid 
 bioer  right  over  the  top  of  them  to 
 begin  to  activate  it  rather  than  waiting 
 for  rain  or  in  addition  to  waiting  for 
 rain  and  using  a  hose  penetrate  is  100% 
 organic  safe  for  people  and  pets  we 
 recommend  two  two  yearly  applications 
 spring  and  fall  but  it's  usable  all 
 throughout  the  year  only  maybe  not  in 
 the  coldest  winter  areas  in  the  middle 
 of  the  winter  for  the  most  comprehensive 
 results  you  just  penetrate  with  our 
 other 
 products

 blend  is  a  proportional  mix  of  our  top 
 three  dry  products  optimize  maximize  and 
 nourish  biosol  optimize  is  concentrated 
 organic  matter  calcium  and  iron  it 
 attracts  and  feeds  zillions  of 
 beneficial  soil  microbes  maximize 
 contains  every  mineral  in  the  periodic 
 table  and  it  has  higher  level  microbes 
 bacteria  fungi  protozoa  nourished  biosol 
 is  an  allnatural  fertilizer  and  soil 
 Builder  made  from  the  cultures  of 
 soybean  meal  and  cotton  seed  meal 
 together  these  three  products  provide 
 you  with  our  most  comprehensive  and  fast 
 soil  building  results  as  well  as  feeding 
 all  your  plants  simultaneously  we 
 recommend  you  use  blend  within  60  days 
 because  sometimes  it  goes  to  work  in  the 
 bag  if  you  try  to  store  it  for  longer 
 especially  if  there's  heat  involved  if 
 you're  concerned  about  this  you  can  buy 
 the  products  separately  and  that  allows 
 you  to  store  them  indefinitely  and  then 
 you  mix  it  yourself  use  a  recipe  of  one 
 two  three  one  part  optimize  two  parts 
 nourish  biosol  three  parts  maximize 
 blend  can  easily  be  applied  by  hand  no 
 need  to  till  it  in  blend  is  great  for

 the  nice  thing  I  like  about  using  our

 soil  as  healthy  as  possible  so  this  is  a 
 40  pound  bag 
 and  we  used  on  this  lawn  which  is  about 
 3  300  3400  square  feet  we  used  two  of 
 these  so  that's  a  very  heavy  application

 pretty  heavy  if  I  know  I  have  fungal 
 problems  I'll  probably  go  25  30  pounds 
 per  thousand  so  I  like  to  just  throw  it 
 on  like  this 
 so  blend  is  a  proportional  mixture  one 
 part  optimized  two  parts  nourish  biosol 
 three  parts  maximized  optimize  is 
 like  concentrated  organic  matter  and 
 that  really  is  a  long-term  type  thing  it 
 breaks  down  slowly  and  it  attracts  all 
 the  beneficial  life  we  want  to  attract 
 but  over  the  long  term  then  the 
 nourished  bowel  is  a  really  good 
 fertilizer  made  from  the  bloom  of 
 cultured  soybean  and  cottonseed  meal 
 that  bloom  is  really  good  at  attracting 
 and  feeding  beneficial  soil  life  and 
 then  the  maximize  that's  the  one  that 
 actually  has  soil  life  in  it  it  has 
 beneficial  bacteria  and  fungi  including 
 the  most  famous  fungi  mycorrhizae  and  it 
 has  a  lot  of  minerals  in  the  form  of 
 ground  up  Basalt  from  old  lava  deposits 
 when  you  put  all  those  together  you've 
 got  a  tremendous  soil  Builder  so  we're 
 throwing  it  on  here  I  don't  usually 
 throw  it  on  with  the  chip  behind  me  but 
 it  is  very  safe  for  pets  and  for  kids 
 you  see  some  dust  I'd  want  to  keep  the 
 dust  away  from  them  so  the  penetrate 
 liquid  bio  tiller  has  two  bottles 
 because  we  want  to  keep  them  separate 
 one  is  the  beneficial  bacteria  and  the 
 other  is  the  food  for  the  bacteria 
 this  is  a  backpack  sprayer  holds  about 
 four  gallons  of  water  I'm  gonna  put 
 about  three  or  four  gallons  of  water  in 
 it  and  it  doesn't  matter  how  much  water 
 you  use  water  is  just  a  carrier  to  get 
 this  product  spread 
 you  see  a  host  bib  anywhere  so  what  I  do

 what  flowers  can  you  plant  this  summer 
 August  through  September  August  is  a 
 transitional  month  Bridging  the  Gap 
 between  the  intense  heat  of  Summer  and 
 the  approaching  cooler  Autumn  weather 
 while  it  may  seem  counterintuitive  to 
 start  planting  during  such  a  warm  period 
 there  are  several  advantages  to  doing  so 
 the  soil  is  still  warm  and  receptive 
 allowing  roots  to  establish  themselves 
 before  the  onset  of  Colder  temperatures 
 without  further  Ado  here  are  10  flowers 
 to  welcome  into  your  garden  before  the 
 summer  is  through  bee  balm  a  colorful 
 plant  that  will  repel  mosquitoes  while 
 simultaneously  attracting  pollinators 
 plant  bee  balm  in  an  area  that  receives 
 several  hours  of  Sun  a  day  in  very  rich 
 well-draining  soil  bee  balm  is  great 
 because  it  will  grow  back  and  multiply 
 each  year 
 celosia 
 celosia  is  a  unique  and  colorful  plant 
 that  adds  interest  to  any  Garden  celosia 
 prefers  to  be  planted  in  areas  that 
 receive  full  sun  in  a  pot  or  directly 
 into  a  garden  bed  something  great  about 
 celosia  is  that  once  established  they 
 are  quite  easy  to  propagate  from  meaning 
 if  you  buy  one  plant  you  can  glean  many 
 more 
 marigolds 
 Marigold  Sprout  rather  quickly  from  seed 
 to  bloom  only  taking  about  eight  weeks 
 marigolds  do  best  when  planted  in  very 
 well  draining  soil  and  are  allowed  to 
 dry  between  waterings 
 Pro  tip  for  marigolds  is  to  water  at  the 
 base  of  the  plant  instead  of  directly  on 
 top  as  marigolds  can  be  finicky  when 
 their  leaves  are  left  wet  marigolds  are 
 also  great  at  repelling  mosquitoes  and 
 rodents  while  simultaneously  attracting 
 pollinators  like  bees  and  butterflies 
 Lantana  Lantana  is  an  extremely  hearty 
 plant  that  does  best  when  planted  in 
 full  sun  when  allowed  to  Lantana  can 
 grow  into  very  large  shrubs  Lantana  is  a 
 great  plant  to  add  to  your  garden  if  you 
 want  something  that  will  Bloom  every 
 year  and  fill  in  large  areas  in  garden 
 beds  Lantana  should  be  watered  well  when 
 first  planted  but  once  established  they 
 are  very  drought  tolerant 
 chrysanthemum  nicknamed  mums  these  large 
 blooming  Beauties  are  sun  loving  and  can 
 be  planted  in  pots  or  in  the  ground 
 though  these  flowers  do  not  live  for 
 long  they  are  quite  something  to  see  as 
 they  bloom  plant  chrysanthemums  one  and 
 a  half to  two  and  a  half  feet  apart 
 depending  on  the  size  of  the  variety 
 Zinnia 
 zinnias  our  fast-growing  drought 
 tolerant  and  easy  maintenance  flowers 
 zinnias  add  vibrant  color  to  any  Garden 
 they  are  planted  in  as  they  come  in  many 
 shades  of  magenta  yellow  orange  and 
 cream  the  best  time  to  plant  zinnia  is 
 anytime  spring  through  late  summer 
 verbena  verbena  also  known  as  verbain 
 comes  in  many  brightly  colored  Hues 
 verbena  needs  to  be  planted  in  an  area 
 that  gets  at  least  8  to  10  hours  of  Sun 
 a  day  verbena  is  known  to  be  a 
 pollinator's  favorite 
 cropsis  also  known  as  tixi  these  little 
 bursts  of  sunshine  are  native  to  the 
 United  States  Mexico  and  Canada 
 tick  seed  flowers  come  in  several 
 varieties  are  full  sun  friendly  and  a 
 great  choice  for  beginner  gardeners 
 China  Aster  different  from  average  Aster 
 the  China  Aster  continues  to  bloom  and 
 grow  long  after  other  plants  are  done 
 blooming  for  the  season  China  Asters 
 come  in  13  different  Hues  are  a 
 fantastic  choice  for  pollinators  and  is 
 an  annual 
 calendula  tearful  looking  pops  of 
 saffron  colored  blooms  calendula  has 
 long  been  used  to  make  topical  tincture 
 for  anti-inflammatory  purposes  these 
 flowers  are  also  edible  and  can  top 
 desserts  or  salads  for  a  spectacular 
 plating  calendula  can  be  planted  in  pots 
 or  in  garden  beds  and  takes  about  six  to 
 eight  weeks  to  bloom  after  an  initial 
 week  of  germination  this  time  of  year  is 
 also  a  great  time  to  prune  back  and 
 deadhead  annual  and  perennial  flowers 
 this  will  help  promote  a  second  Bloom 
 don't  forget  before  planting  in  ground 
 improve  your  existing  soil  by  mixing  in 
 compost  or  other  Rich  organic  matter  if 
 you  don't  have  access  to  compost  we 
 recommend  using  our  100  organic  people 
 and  pet  safe  soil  amendments  it's  all 
 the  great  organic  benefits  of  composting

 this  video  interesting  leave  us  a 
 comment  or  hit  the  like  button
